item.title: Foundations of Quantum Granular Computing with Effect-Based Granules, Algebraic Properties and Reference Architectures
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Quantum Granular Computing, effect operators, Born probabilities, Helstrom measurement, quantum decision systems

Summary: This paper establishes the foundational framework of Quantum Granular Computing (QGC), extending traditional granular computing methods such as fuzzy, rough, and shadowed granules into the quantum domain. Quantum granules are represented as effects on finite-dimensional Hilbert spaces, utilizing Born probabilities to model granular memberships, which unifies sharp (projective) and soft (nonprojective) granules within quantum information theory. Key theoretical results include normalization and monotonicity of quantum granules, the formation of Boolean substructures from commuting operators, and the behavior of granules under Luders state updates and quantum channels viewed via the Heisenberg picture. QGC is linked to quantum detection and estimation through the interpretation of Helstrom minimum error effect operators as quantum analogs of Bayes optimal decision regions, termed Helstrom type decision granules. The paper proposes Quantum Granular Decision Systems (QGDS) with three architectures that combine quantum granular computing with classical components suitable for near-term quantum devices. Case studies demonstrate QGC on qubits and two-qubit systems, highlighting graded memberships, smooth decision boundaries, and quantum phenomena like noncommutativity, contextuality, and entanglement. Overall, QGC offers a comprehensive, mathematically rigorous operator-valued granular framework for quantum information processing, granular reasoning, and intelligent system design.
arXiv:2511.22679v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: This paper develops the foundations of Quantum Granular Computing (QGC), extending classical granular computing including fuzzy, rough, and shadowed granules to the quantum regime. Quantum granules are modeled as effects on a finite dimensional Hilbert space, so granular memberships are given by Born probabilities. This operator theoretic viewpoint provides a common language for sharp (projective) and soft (nonprojective) granules and embeds granulation directly into the standard formalism of quantum information theory. We establish foundational results for effect based quantum granules, including normalization and monotonicity properties, the emergence of Boolean islands from commuting families, granular refinement under Luders updates, and the evolution of granules under quantum channels via the adjoint channel in the Heisenberg picture. We connect QGC with quantum detection and estimation theory by interpreting the effect operators realizing Helstrom minimum error measurement for binary state discrimination as Helstrom type decision granules, i.e., soft quantum counterparts of Bayes optimal decision regions. Building on these results, we introduce Quantum Granular Decision Systems (QGDS) with three reference architectures that specify how quantum granules can be defined, learned, and integrated with classical components while remaining compatible with near term quantum hardware. Case studies on qubit granulation, two qubit parity effects, and Helstrom style soft decisions illustrate how QGC reproduces fuzzy like graded memberships and smooth decision boundaries while exploiting noncommutativity, contextuality, and entanglement. The framework thus provides a unified and mathematically grounded basis for operator valued granules in quantum information processing, granular reasoning, and intelligent systems.

item.title: Probabilistic Fusion and Calibration of Neural Speaker Diarization Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: End-to-End Neural Diarization, calibration, probability-level fusion, DOVER-Lap, diarization error rate

Summary: This paper addresses the gap in calibration and confidence reliability of End-to-End Neural Diarization (EEND) systems, which typically produce frame-level probabilistic speaker activity estimates but are mostly evaluated using Diarization Error Rate (DER). It proposes a novel framework for calibrating and fusing EEND outputs at the probability level, enabling more nuanced fusion techniques that exploit model uncertainty and the complementary strengths of different architectures. Two output representations are analyzed: multilabel and powerset, revealing that powerset-based joint calibration consistently outperforms independent per-speaker calibration schemes. Experiments on the CallHome two-speaker benchmark demonstrate that proper calibration significantly reduces DER (up to 19% relative improvement), even alleviating the need for domain adaptation in some cases. The study further shows that fusing multiple systems at the probability level surpasses the performance of individual models. Among fusion strategies, the ordering of Fuse-then-Calibrate outperforms other approaches, requiring calibration of only one combined model rather than multiple individual models, resulting in better DER and calibration quality. The proposed approach also outperforms the established DOVER-Lap method, which currently fuses only hard decisions at the segment level. This research establishes best practices for effective soft-output fusion and calibration, enhancing both diarization accuracy and the reliability of confidence estimates essential for downstream applications.
arXiv:2511.22696v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: End-to-End Neural Diarization (EEND) systems produce frame-level probabilistic speaker activity estimates, yet since evaluation focuses primarily on Diarization Error Rate (DER), the reliability and calibration of these confidence scores have been largely neglected. When fusing multiple diarization systems, DOVER-Lap remains the only established approach, operating at the segment level with hard decisions. We propose working with continuous probability outputs, which enables more sophisticated fusion and calibration techniques that can leverage model uncertainty and complementary strengths across different architectures. This paper presents the first comprehensive framework for calibrating and fusing EEND models at the probability level. We investigate two output formulations (multilabel and powerset representations) and their impact on calibration and fusion effectiveness. Through extensive experiments on the CallHome two-speaker benchmark, we demonstrate that proper calibration provides substantial improvements even for individual models (up to 19% relative DER reduction), in some cases mitigating the absence of domain adaptation. We reveal that joint calibration in powerset space consistently outperforms independent per-speaker calibration, that fusion substantially improves over individual models, and that the Fuse-then-Calibrate ordering generally outperforms both calibrating before fusion and uncalibrated fusion while requiring calibration of only a single combined model. Our best configuration outperforms DOVER-Lap in terms of DER while providing reliable confidence estimates essential for downstream applications. This work proposes best practices for probability-level fusion of EEND systems and demonstrates the advantages of leveraging soft outputs over hard decisions.

item.title: Exploring Syntropic Frameworks in AI Alignment: A Philosophical Investigation
item.content:encoded:
AI alignment, syntropy, specification trap, moral capacity, multi-agent systems

Summary: The paper argues for a redefinition of AI alignment, advocating for the creation of syntropic, reasons-responsive agents through developmental, multi-agent processes instead of relying on fixed human value encoding. First, it introduces the "specification trap," highlighting the instability of content-based value specification due to the is-ought gap, value pluralism, and the extended frame problem. Second, the paper presents syntropy as an information-theoretic concept describing the recursive reduction of mutual uncertainty between agents via state alignment, offering a new lens on multi-agent alignment dynamics. Third, the author distinguishes between genuine and simulated moral capacities, rooting this distinction in compatibilist theories of guidance control and proposing an embodied experimental framework alongside a verification regime that operate independently of subjective phenomenological claims. This foundational philosophical work forms part of a larger research program, with empirical validation and testing underway in a separate, forthcoming project. While the proposed framework yields concrete, falsifiable predictions concerning value emergence and moral agency in AI systems, experimental confirmation has yet to be achieved.
arXiv:2512.03048v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: I argue that AI alignment should be reconceived as architecting syntropic, reasons-responsive agents through process-based, multi-agent, developmental mechanisms rather than encoding fixed human value content. The paper makes three philosophical contributions. First, I articulate the ``specification trap'' argument demonstrating why content-based value specification appears structurally unstable due to the conjunction of the is-ought gap, value pluralism, and the extended frame problem. Second, I propose syntropy -- the recursive reduction of mutual uncertainty between agents through state alignment -- as an information-theoretic framework for understanding multi-agent alignment dynamics. Third, I establish a functional distinction between genuine and simulated moral capacity grounded in compatibilist theories of guidance control, coupled with an embodied experimental paradigm and verification regime providing operational criteria independent of phenomenological claims. This paper represents the philosophical component of a broader research program whose empirical validation is being developed in a separate project currently in preparation. While the framework generates specific, falsifiable predictions about value emergence and moral agency in artificial systems, empirical validation remains pending.

item.title: Beyond the Black Box: A Cognitive Architecture for Explainable and Aligned AI
item.content:encoded:
Weight-Calculatism, Artificial General Intelligence, Explainability, Value Alignment, Cognitive Architecture

Summary: This paper presents Weight-Calculatism, a new cognitive architecture aimed at addressing critical challenges in current AI paradigms, especially explainability and value alignment. The architecture breaks down cognition into basic elements called Logical Atoms and centers around two primary operations: Pointing and Comparison. Decision-making within the system is governed by a Weight-Calculation model, where Weight is computed as the product of Benefit and Probability. These weights originate from an auditable and transparent set of Initial Weights, ensuring traceability and transparency. This atomic cognitive decomposition supports radical explainability and intrinsic generality, enabling the system to adapt to novel situations robustly. The architecture's design leverages graph-algorithm-based computational engines and operates through a global workspace workflow, facilitating systematic processing of information. The paper discusses the implementation of a preliminary code base and validates the model through scenario testing. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves transparent, human-like reasoning and robust learning capabilities, even in unprecedented scenarios. The approach provides a practical and theoretical foundation for developing trustworthy AGI aligned with human values and interpretable decision processes, marking a significant advancement in the pursuit of explainable and aligned artificial intelligence.
arXiv:2512.03072v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Current AI paradigms, as "architects of experience," face fundamental challenges in explainability and value alignment. This paper introduces "Weight-Calculatism," a novel cognitive architecture grounded in first principles, and demonstrates its potential as a viable pathway toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). The architecture deconstructs cognition into indivisible Logical Atoms and two fundamental operations: Pointing and Comparison. Decision-making is formalized through an interpretable Weight-Calculation model (Weight = Benefit * Probability), where all values are traceable to an auditable set of Initial Weights. This atomic decomposition enables radical explainability, intrinsic generality for novel situations, and traceable value alignment. We detail its implementation via a graph-algorithm-based computational engine and a global workspace workflow, supported by a preliminary code implementation and scenario validation. Results indicate that the architecture achieves transparent, human-like reasoning and robust learning in unprecedented scenarios, establishing a practical and theoretical foundation for building trustworthy and aligned AGI.

item.title: When Do Symbolic Solvers Enhance Reasoning in Large Language Models?
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Reasoning Models, Chains of Thought, symbolic solver, constraint satisfaction, code generation

Summary:

1. Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) improve performance on complex reasoning tasks by generating long Chains of Thought (CoTs), but this approach can lead to excessive token usage and "overthinking," sometimes resulting in incorrect answers. 2. An alternative approach integrates symbolic solvers with LRMs by translating reasoning tasks into executable code via large language models’ code generation capabilities, allowing symbolic solvers to handle problem-solving more efficiently. 3. The study investigates when conventional long-CoT reasoning can be enhanced through the inclusion of symbolic solvers and finds that the symbolic-solver-integrated method helps mainly when problems have limited implicit reasoning but involve large search spaces. 4. Latest LLMs such as GPT-4o excel in deductive problems requiring shallow reasoning but benefit less from symbolic solvers. In contrast, constraint satisfaction problems requiring repeated backtracking show significant performance gains with symbolic-solver integration. 5. Providing a declarative exemplar enables smaller models (e.g., CodeLlama-13B) to surpass GPT-4o’s performance in complex problems like Zebra puzzles, highlighting the potential of combining symbolic reasoning and LLMs for challenging tasks.
arXiv:2512.03272v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) achieve strong performance on complex reasoning tasks by generating long Chains of Thought (CoTs). However, this paradigm might incur substantial token overhead, especially when models "overthink" by producing lengthy reasoning chains, which can even lead to incorrect answers. A promising direction is the symbolic-solver-integrated approach, which leverages the code generation capabilities of LLMs to translate reasoning tasks into executable code and then solve them with a symbolic solver. In this paper, we explore an open question of when the conventional long-CoT can be enhanced by symbolic solvers. Our experimental results show that the symbolic-solver-integrated method only helps when the problem requires limited implicit reasoning but involves an ample search space. The latest LLMs, like GPT-4o, show better performance on deductive problems with shallow reasoning depth, while the symbolic-solver-integrated method significantly improves the LLMs' performance in constraint satisfaction problems that require repeated backtracks. When a declarative exemplar is provided, even CodeLlama-13B can outperform GPT-4o in difficult Zebra puzzles.

item.title: Prior preferences in active inference agents: soft, hard, and goal shaping
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: active inference, expected free energy, preference distribution, goal shaping, exploration-exploitation trade-off

Summary: This article investigates the role of the preference distribution in active inference, which is crucial for balancing exploitative and explorative drives in learning agents. Active inference uses expected free energy as a planning objective, where the exploitative drive is quantified by the Kullback-Leibler divergence between a variational distribution and the preference distribution that encodes the agent's goals. Despite its importance, prior research has largely neglected how the preference distribution should be defined and its consequences for agent performance. The authors propose and examine four variants of preference distributions that either implement hard or soft goals, with or without goal shaping (intermediate goals). These four agent types are tested in a grid world navigation task to evaluate their performance. Results indicate that agents with goal shaping achieve superior performance by promoting exploitation of learned knowledge. However, this comes at the cost of diminished exploration and less effective learning of transition dynamics within the environment. The study therefore highlights the trade-off between exploiting goal-directed behavior and exploring the environment when specifying preference distributions in active inference frameworks. This work contributes to understanding how goal definitions impact learning and decision-making in artificial agents under the active inference paradigm.
arXiv:2512.03293v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Active inference proposes expected free energy as an objective for planning and decision-making to adequately balance exploitative and explorative drives in learning agents. The exploitative drive, or what an agent wants to achieve, is formalised as the Kullback-Leibler divergence between a variational probability distribution, updated at each inference step, and a preference probability distribution that indicates what states or observations are more likely for the agent, hence determining the agent's goal in a certain environment. In the literature, the questions of how the preference distribution should be specified and of how a certain specification impacts inference and learning in an active inference agent have been given hardly any attention. In this work, we consider four possible ways of defining the preference distribution, either providing the agents with hard or soft goals and either involving or not goal shaping (i.e., intermediate goals). We compare the performances of four agents, each given one of the possible preference distributions, in a grid world navigation task. Our results show that goal shaping enables the best performance overall (i.e., it promotes exploitation) while sacrificing learning about the environment's transition dynamics (i.e., it hampers exploration).

item.title: Evaluating Generalization Capabilities of LLM-Based Agents in Mixed-Motive Scenarios Using Concordia
item.content:encoded:
LLM agents, social interaction, cooperation, Concordia, generalization

Summary: This paper addresses the evaluation of Large Language Model (LLM) agents in their ability to cooperate in mixed-motive social environments, which involve both human and artificial agents. It highlights the inadequacy of existing evaluation methods to test how well these agents generalize to novel social situations. The authors propose a new evaluation method leveraging Concordia, a natural language multi-agent simulation environment, to assess general cooperative intelligence. This method tests agents’ capabilities to identify and exploit opportunities for mutual benefit across a diverse range of partners and contexts without prior training (zero-shot). The paper presents empirical results from the NeurIPS 2024 Concordia Contest, which featured tasks including negotiation and collective action problems, showcasing agents' performance in achieving mutual gains. Findings reveal notable performance gaps between current agent capabilities and the level of robust generalization necessary for trustworthy cooperation. These gaps are especially pronounced in scenarios requiring complex skills such as persuasion and norm enforcement. The work underscores the challenges faced by LLM-based agents in social cooperation and the importance of developing more effective generalization evaluation frameworks to advance their deployment in real-world social contexts.
arXiv:2512.03318v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Model (LLM) agents have demonstrated impressive capabilities for social interaction and are increasingly being deployed in situations where they might engage with both human and artificial agents. These interactions represent a critical frontier for LLM-based agents, yet existing evaluation methods fail to measure how well these capabilities generalize to novel social situations. In this paper, we introduce a method for evaluating the ability of LLM-based agents to cooperate in zero-shot, mixed-motive environments using Concordia, a natural language multi-agent simulation environment. Our method measures general cooperative intelligence by testing an agent's ability to identify and exploit opportunities for mutual gain across diverse partners and contexts. We present empirical results from the NeurIPS 2024 Concordia Contest, where agents were evaluated on their ability to achieve mutual gains across a suite of diverse scenarios ranging from negotiation to collective action problems. Our findings reveal significant gaps between current agent capabilities and the robust generalization required for reliable cooperation, particularly in scenarios demanding persuasion and norm enforcement.

item.title: Multimodal Reinforcement Learning with Agentic Verifier for AI Agents
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal reinforcement learning, agentic reasoning, reward design, SFT curation, reward-hacking

Summary:
1. This paper addresses the limitation in multimodal reinforcement learning (MMRL) for agentic reasoning models, which traditionally use sparse, outcome-based rewards that focus only on final answers.
2. The authors propose Argos (Agentic Reward for Grounded & Objective Scoring), a reward agent designed to provide richer, more fine-grained feedback by selecting from various teacher-model and rule-based scoring functions tailored to each sample.
3. Argos evaluates final response accuracy, spatiotemporal localization of entities and actions, and the quality of the reasoning process, thereby offering a multi-dimensional reward signal.
4. The approach enhances both supervised fine-tuning (SFT) data curation and reinforcement learning (RL) training, achieving state-of-the-art performance in tasks involving spatial reasoning, visual hallucination, and embodied AI including robotics.
5. The paper highlights that solely relying on SFT with curated reasoning data is insufficient, as agents can drift toward ungrounded reasoning during RL without Argos' online verification, which also helps mitigate reward-hacking.
6. Finally, the authors provide a theoretical justification of Argos’ effectiveness through the concept of Pareto-optimality, showing its principled foundation in balancing multiple objectives.
arXiv:2512.03438v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Agentic reasoning models trained with multimodal reinforcement learning (MMRL) have become increasingly capable, yet they are almost universally optimized using sparse, outcome-based rewards computed based on the final answers. Richer rewards computed from the reasoning tokens can improve learning significantly by providing more fine-grained guidance. However, it is challenging to compute more informative rewards in MMRL beyond those based on outcomes since different samples may require different scoring functions and teacher models may provide noisy reward signals too. In this paper, we introduce the Argos (Agentic Reward for Grounded & Objective Scoring), a principled reward agent to train multimodal reasoning models for agentic tasks. For each sample, Argos selects from a pool of teacher-model derived and rule-based scoring functions to simultaneously evaluate: (i) final response accuracy, (ii) spatiotemporal localization of referred entities and actions, and (iii) the quality of the reasoning process. We find that by leveraging our agentic verifier across both SFT data curation and RL training, our model achieves state-of-the-art results across multiple agentic tasks such as spatial reasoning, visual hallucination as well as robotics and embodied AI benchmarks. Critically, we demonstrate that just relying on SFT post-training on highly curated reasoning data is insufficient, as agents invariably collapse to ungrounded solutions during RL without our online verification. We also show that our agentic verifier can help to reduce reward-hacking in MMRL. Finally, we also provide a theoretical justification for the effectiveness of Argos through the concept of pareto-optimality.

item.title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Communication-Constrained Priors
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multi-agent reinforcement learning, communication constraints, lossy communication, mutual information, distributed decision-making

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges of lossy communication in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems operating in complex and dynamic real-world environments. First, it proposes a generalized communication-constrained model that uniformly characterizes different communication conditions across various scenarios, creating a consistent framework to handle communication limitations. Second, the model is used as a learning prior to differentiate between lossy and lossless messages in order to adapt communication strategies tailored to specific settings. Third, the study decouples the effects of lossy and lossless message transmissions on distributed decision-making by employing a dual mutual information estimator, which helps to better quantify the relevance and impact of received messages. Fourth, this insight leads to the introduction of a communication-constrained MARL framework that explicitly quantifies the influence of communication messages into the global reward function, thereby improving learning efficiency and robustness under communication constraints. Finally, the effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated experimentally on several communication-constrained benchmarks, showing improved scalability and robustness compared to existing communication-enabled MARL methods.
arXiv:2512.03528v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Communication is one of the effective means to improve the learning of cooperative policy in multi-agent systems. However, in most real-world scenarios, lossy communication is a prevalent issue. Existing multi-agent reinforcement learning with communication, due to their limited scalability and robustness, struggles to apply to complex and dynamic real-world environments. To address these challenges, we propose a generalized communication-constrained model to uniformly characterize communication conditions across different scenarios. Based on this, we utilize it as a learning prior to distinguish between lossy and lossless messages for specific scenarios. Additionally, we decouple the impact of lossy and lossless messages on distributed decision-making, drawing on a dual mutual information estimatior, and introduce a communication-constrained multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, quantifying the impact of communication messages into the global reward. Finally, we validate the effectiveness of our approach across several communication-constrained benchmarks.

item.title: PARC: An Autonomous Self-Reflective Coding Agent for Robust Execution of Long-Horizon Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PARC, hierarchical multi-agent system, self-assessment, long-horizon tasks, autonomous execution

Summary:

1. The paper presents PARC, a coding agent designed for autonomous and robust execution of long-horizon computational tasks by leveraging a hierarchical multi-agent architecture.
2. PARC integrates task planning, execution, and a novel self-assessment and self-feedback mechanism that evaluates its own actions independently and provides corrective feedback to improve performance.
3. This architecture allows PARC to detect and correct high-level strategic errors without human intervention, sustaining progress throughout complex workflows.
4. Evaluation of PARC covers domains such as materials science, where it autonomously reproduces significant results in lithium-ion conduction and alloy segregation by managing multiple parallel simulation tasks lasting approximately 43 hours each.
5. In data science, PARC successfully performs Kaggle-based data analysis, starting from minimal natural-language instructions and implementing search strategies that yield solutions competitive with human-engineered baselines.

These results demonstrate the potential of combining hierarchical multi-agent systems with self-assessment capabilities to create AI agents capable of independent, large-scale scientific and analytical work.
arXiv:2512.03549v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce PARC, a coding agent for the autonomous and robust execution of long-horizon computational tasks. PARC is built on a hierarchical multi-agent architecture incorporating task planning, execution, and a mechanism that evaluates its own actions and their outcomes from an independent context and provides feedback, namely self-assessment and self-feedback. This design enables PARC to detect and correct high-level strategic errors and sustain progress without human intervention. We evaluate PARC across computational science and data science tasks. In materials science, it autonomously reproduces key results from studies on lithium-ion conduction and alloy segregation. In particular, it coordinates dozens of parallel simulation tasks, each requiring roughly 43 hours of computation, managing orchestration, monitoring, and error correction end-to-end. In Kaggle-based experiments, starting from minimal natural-language instructions, PARC conducts data analysis and implements search strategies, producing solutions competitive with human-engineered baselines. These results highlight the potential of integrating a hierarchical multi-agent system with self-assessment and self-feedback to enable AI systems capable of independent, large-scale scientific and analytical work.

item.title: Reason-Plan-ReAct: A Reasoner-Planner Supervising a ReAct Executor for Complex Enterprise Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: autonomous agents, multi-agent system, RP-ReAct, context window management, enterprise tasks

Summary:

Despite recent progress, autonomous agents face difficulties in solving complex enterprise tasks that require coordinating multiple tools and processing varied data sources. Two primary challenges are identified: first, single-agent architectures utilize a monolithic plan-execute loop that causes trajectory instability; second, data privacy constraints necessitate local open-weight models with smaller context windows, which rapidly consume context when handling large tool outputs. To address these issues, the paper proposes RP-ReAct (Reasoner Planner-ReAct), a novel multi-agent framework that separates strategic planning from low-level execution, enhancing reliability and efficiency. RP-ReAct consists of a Reasoner Planner Agent (RPA) tasked with planning sub-steps and analyzing execution outcomes using a powerful Large Reasoning Model, and one or more Proxy-Execution Agents (PEA) that convert sub-steps into tool interactions following a ReAct methodology. A key innovation is a context-saving strategy within the PEA, which manages large outputs by leveraging external storage and on-demand access, mitigating context window overflow. Evaluation on the multi-domain ToolQA benchmark with six different open-weight reasoning models shows RP-ReAct’s superiority in performance and generalization against state-of-the-art baselines across diverse complex tasks. Additionally, RP-ReAct demonstrates enhanced robustness and stability across various model scales, supporting its potential as an effective, deployable solution for enterprise-level agentic applications.
arXiv:2512.03560v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Despite recent advances, autonomous agents often struggle to solve complex tasks in enterprise domains that require coordinating multiple tools and processing diverse data sources. This struggle is driven by two main limitations. First, single-agent architectures enforce a monolithic plan-execute loop, which directly causes trajectory instability. Second, the requirement to use local open-weight models for data privacy introduces smaller context windows leading to the rapid consumption of context from large tool outputs. To solve this problem we introduce RP-ReAct (Reasoner Planner-ReAct), a novel multi-agent approach that fundamentally decouples strategic planning from low-level execution to achieve superior reliability and efficiency. RP-ReAct consists of a Reasoner Planner Agent (RPA), responsible for planning each sub-step, continuously analysing the execution results using the strong reasoning capabilities of a Large Reasoning Model, and one or multiple Proxy-Execution Agent (PEA) that translates sub-steps into concrete tool interactions using a ReAct approach. Crucially, we incorporate a context-saving strategy within the PEA to mitigate context window overflow by managing large tool outputs via external storage and on-demand access. We evaluate RP-ReAct, on the challenging, multi-domain ToolQA benchmark using a diverse set of six open-weight reasoning models. Our empirical results show that RP-ReAct achieves superior performance and improved generalization ability over state-of-the-art baselines when addressing diverse complex tasks across the evaluated domains. Furthermore we establish the enhanced robustness and stability of our approach across different model scales, paving the way for effective and deployable agentic solutions for enterprises.

item.title: EnCompass: Enhancing Agent Programming with Search Over Program Execution Paths
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: agent programming, probabilistic angelic nondeterminism, LLM-based agents, inference-time strategies, EnCompass framework

Summary: This paper introduces a novel approach to designing agents, specifically those based on large language models (LLMs). The key innovation is a programming model called probabilistic angelic nondeterminism (PAN), which separates the core workflow logic of an agent from its inference-time strategy, such as tree search methods. This separation enables programmers to independently define the agent’s workflow and easily experiment with various inference methods by modifying only a few parameters. The authors implement PAN in Python through the EnCompass framework, which leverages a Python decorator to transform agent workflows into searchable spaces, streamlining the development and testing process. To validate their approach, the paper presents three case studies demonstrating the framework’s practical benefits. These include improving agent reliability and facilitating effortless switching between different inference-time strategies with minimal additional coding. Overall, the EnCompass framework powered by PAN promises greater flexibility, modularity, and ease in developing sophisticated LLM-based agents, addressing the common problem of entangling workflow and inference logic in current methodologies.
arXiv:2512.03571v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce a new approach to agent programming, the development of LLM-based agents. Current approaches to agent programming often entangle two aspects of agent design: the core workflow logic and the inference-time strategy (e.g., tree search). We introduce "probabilistic angelic nondeterminism" ("PAN"), a programming model that disentangles these two concerns, allowing the programmer to describe the agent workflow and independently experiment with different inference-time strategies by simply changing a few inputs. We provide an implementation of PAN in Python as the EnCompass framework, which uses a Python decorator to compile agent workflow programs into a search space. We present three case studies that demonstrate how the framework lets the programmer quickly improve the reliability of an agent and easily switch between different inference-time strategies, all with little additional coding.

item.title: DeepRule: An Integrated Framework for Automated Business Rule Generation via Deep Predictive Modeling and Hybrid Search Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: DeepRule, business rule generation, retail pricing optimization, large language models, game-theoretic optimization

Summary:

This paper introduces DeepRule, a novel framework designed to automate business rule generation for retail assortment and pricing optimization. It addresses three key challenges: the mismatch between unstructured textual data and accurate customer profiling, the complexity in modeling dynamic, nonlinear price elasticity and feature interactions, and the difficulty of operationalizing multi-tier business constraints. To overcome these, DeepRule employs a tri-level architecture. First, it uses a hybrid knowledge fusion engine with large language models (LLMs) to semantically parse unstructured texts like negotiation records and approval documents, converting them into structured data enriched by managerial expertise. Second, it applies a game-theoretic constrained optimization mechanism that balances manufacturer and distributor interests through bilateral utility functions while handling hierarchical constraints to ensure feasible operations. Third, it integrates an interpretable decision distillation interface where LLM-guided symbolic regression derives and optimizes pricing strategies alongside auditable business rules, embedding economic priors such as non-negative price elasticity as hard constraints in the mathematical expressions. Validation in real retail settings shows the framework outperforms traditional business-to-consumer baselines in profitability and operational feasibility. Overall, DeepRule offers a closed-loop pipeline combining unstructured knowledge integration, multi-agent optimization, and interpretable strategy synthesis to advance economic intelligence in retail.
arXiv:2512.03607v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper proposes DeepRule, an integrated framework for automated business rule generation in retail assortment and pricing optimization. Addressing the systematic misalignment between existing theoretical models and real-world economic complexities, we identify three critical gaps: (1) data modality mismatch where unstructured textual sources (e.g. negotiation records, approval documents) impede accurate customer profiling; (2) dynamic feature entanglement challenges in modeling nonlinear price elasticity and time-varying attributes; (3) operational infeasibility caused by multi-tier business constraints. Our framework introduces a tri-level architecture for above challenges. We design a hybrid knowledge fusion engine employing large language models (LLMs) for deep semantic parsing of unstructured text, transforming distributor agreements and sales assessments into structured features while integrating managerial expertise. Then a game-theoretic constrained optimization mechanism is employed to dynamically reconcile supply chain interests through bilateral utility functions, encoding manufacturer-distributor profit redistribution as endogenous objectives under hierarchical constraints. Finally an interpretable decision distillation interface leveraging LLM-guided symbolic regression to find and optimize pricing strategies and auditable business rules embeds economic priors (e.g. non-negative elasticity) as hard constraints during mathematical expression search. We validate the framework in real retail environments achieving higher profits versus systematic B2C baselines while ensuring operational feasibility. This establishes a close-loop pipeline unifying unstructured knowledge injection, multi-agent optimization, and interpretable strategy synthesis for real economic intelligence.

item.title: MemVerse: Multimodal Memory for Lifelong Learning Agents
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: MemVerse, memory framework, multimodal intelligence, hierarchical knowledge graphs, continual learning

Summary:

1. The paper introduces MemVerse, a novel memory framework designed to address the fundamental limitation of AI agents' inability to remember past experiences effectively.
2. MemVerse is model-agnostic and plug-and-play, integrating fast parametric recall with a hierarchical, retrieval-based memory system to enhance scalable and adaptive multimodal intelligence.
3. The framework maintains short-term memory for recent contexts and simultaneously structures raw multimodal experiences into long-term memories organized as hierarchical knowledge graphs.
4. This design supports continual memory consolidation, adaptive forgetting, and bounded growth, allowing agents to handle extended interactions without overwhelming memory demands.
5. To meet real-time processing requirements, MemVerse employs a periodic distillation mechanism that compresses critical knowledge from long-term memory into the parametric model, enabling fast, differentiable recall while keeping the memory interpretable.
6. Experimental results show that MemVerse significantly boosts multimodal reasoning capabilities and improves continual learning efficiency.
7. Ultimately, the framework empowers AI agents to remember, adapt, and reason coherently over long horizons and complex interactive environments, overcoming key challenges in current AI systems.
arXiv:2512.03627v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Despite rapid progress in large-scale language and vision models, AI agents still suffer from a fundamental limitation: they cannot remember. Without reliable memory, agents catastrophically forget past experiences, struggle with long-horizon reasoning, and fail to operate coherently in multimodal or interactive environments. We introduce MemVerse, a model-agnostic, plug-and-play memory framework that bridges fast parametric recall with hierarchical retrieval-based memory, enabling scalable and adaptive multimodal intelligence. MemVerse maintains short-term memory for recent context while transforming raw multimodal experiences into structured long-term memories organized as hierarchical knowledge graphs. This design supports continual consolidation, adaptive forgetting, and bounded memory growth. To handle real-time demands, MemVerse introduces a periodic distillation mechanism that compresses essential knowledge from long-term memory into the parametric model, allowing fast, differentiable recall while preserving interpretability. Extensive experiments demonstrate that MemVerse significantly improves multimodal reasoning and continual learning efficiency, empowering agents to remember, adapt, and reason coherently across extended interactions.

item.title: RoCo: Role-Based LLMs Collaboration for Automatic Heuristic Design
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Automatic Heuristic Design, Large Language Models, Multi-Agent System, Combinatorial Optimization, Multi-Role Collaboration

Summary: This paper introduces RoCo, a novel Multi-Agent Role-Based System designed to improve Automatic Heuristic Design (AHD) for combinatorial optimization problems (COPs). Unlike prior approaches that utilize Large Language Models (LLMs) in a single-role capacity, RoCo leverages four specialized LLM-guided agents—explorer, exploiter, critic, and integrator—working collaboratively to generate higher-quality heuristics. The explorer agent emphasizes creativity and diversity by promoting long-term potential solutions, while the exploiter targets immediate efficiency and short-term improvements through conservative refinements. The critic plays a vital role by evaluating each step’s effectiveness and providing precise feedback and reflection. Meanwhile, the integrator balances innovation and exploitation by synthesizing the contributions from the explorer and exploiter to ensure steady overall progress. The interactions among these agents follow a structured multi-round process that fosters feedback, refinement, and elite mutations grounded in both short-term gains and accumulated long-term reflections. The system’s performance was assessed on five different COPs under both white-box and black-box experimental conditions. Results show RoCo consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods such as ReEvo and HSEvo, establishing a new paradigm for robust, collaborative AHD leveraging multi-role LLM agents.
arXiv:2512.03762v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Automatic Heuristic Design (AHD) has gained traction as a promising solution for solving combinatorial optimization problems (COPs). Large Language Models (LLMs) have emerged and become a promising approach to achieving AHD, but current LLM-based AHD research often only considers a single role. This paper proposes RoCo, a novel Multi-Agent Role-Based System, to enhance the diversity and quality of AHD through multi-role collaboration. RoCo coordinates four specialized LLM-guided agents-explorer, exploiter, critic, and integrator-to collaboratively generate high-quality heuristics. The explorer promotes long-term potential through creative, diversity-driven thinking, while the exploiter focuses on short-term improvements via conservative, efficiency-oriented refinements. The critic evaluates the effectiveness of each evolution step and provides targeted feedback and reflection. The integrator synthesizes proposals from the explorer and exploiter, balancing innovation and exploitation to drive overall progress. These agents interact in a structured multi-round process involving feedback, refinement, and elite mutations guided by both short-term and accumulated long-term reflections. We evaluate RoCo on five different COPs under both white-box and black-box settings. Experimental results demonstrate that RoCo achieves superior performance, consistently generating competitive heuristics that outperform existing methods including ReEvo and HSEvo, both in white-box and black-box scenarios. This role-based collaborative paradigm establishes a new standard for robust and high-performing AHD.

item.title: Omni-AutoThink: Adaptive Multimodal Reasoning via Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Omni-AutoThink, adaptive reasoning, multimodal models, reinforcement learning, benchmark

Summary: This paper presents Omni-AutoThink, an innovative adaptive reasoning framework designed to enhance the reasoning flexibility of Omni models across multimodal tasks. The framework dynamically modulates the model's reasoning depth in response to task difficulty, avoiding pitfalls of rigid or ineffective reasoning. It consists of two key stages: first, Adaptive Supervised Fine-Tuning (Adaptive SFT), which imparts foundational reasoning skills via extensive reasoning-augmented datasets; second, Adaptive Reinforcement Learning (Adaptive GRPO), which fine-tunes reasoning strategies by leveraging task complexity and reward signals. To comprehensively evaluate and train such adaptive reasoning capabilities, the authors introduce a new benchmark encompassing various modalities including text-only, text-audio, text-visual, and fully multimodal text-audio-visual tasks. This benchmark provides both training and evaluation datasets tailored for multimodal reasoning assessments. Experimental results demonstrate that Omni-AutoThink substantially outperforms existing baseline methods in adaptive reasoning scenarios, showcasing improved responsiveness and efficiency. The authors plan to publicly release all related code and benchmark data, fostering further research and development in adaptive multimodal reasoning systems.
arXiv:2512.03783v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in Omni models have enabled unified multimodal perception and generation. However, most existing systems still exhibit rigid reasoning behaviors, either overthinking simple problems or failing to reason when necessary. To address this limitation, we propose Omni-AutoThink, a novel adaptive reasoning framework that dynamically adjusts the model's reasoning depth according to task difficulty. Our framework comprises two stages: (1) an Adaptive Supervised Fine-Tuning (Adaptive SFT) stage, which endows the Omni model with fundamental reasoning capability using large-scale reasoning-augmented data, and (2) an Adaptive Reinforcement Learning (Adaptive GRPO) stage, which optimizes reasoning behaviors based on task complexity and reward feedback. We further construct a comprehensive adaptive reasoning benchmark that spans text-only, text-audio, text-visual, and text-audio-visual modalities, providing both training and evaluation splits for multimodal reasoning assessment. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed framework significantly improves adaptive reasoning performance compared to previous baselines. All benchmark data and code will be publicly released.

item.title: A Hierarchical Tree-based approach for creating Configurable and Static Deep Research Agent (Static-DRA)
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Deep Research Agents, Static-DRA, Depth and Breadth parameters, multi-hop information retrieval

Summary: This paper presents the Static Deep Research Agent (Static-DRA), a novel agentic system designed to enhance complex, multi-turn research tasks beyond traditional static Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) systems. The Static-DRA is based on a hierarchical, tree-structured static workflow that can be finely configured using two user-tunable parameters: Depth and Breadth. These parameters allow users to control research intensity, balancing between the comprehensiveness and quality of the research output and the computational cost of interactions with Large Language Models (LLMs). The agent’s architecture consists of three roles—Supervisor, Independent, and Worker agents—which together enable effective multi-hop information retrieval and parallel investigation of sub-topics to deepen the research process. Evaluation using the DeepResearch Bench and the RACE framework demonstrated that when configured with a Depth of 2 and Breadth of 5, and running on the gemini-2.5-pro model, Static-DRA achieved an overall score of 34.72. The results confirm that increasing Depth and Breadth leads to more comprehensive research and higher evaluation scores. The Static-DRA provides a practical, resource-aware solution that offers transparent user control over the research complexity. The full source code, output data, and benchmarks are publicly available on GitHub.
arXiv:2512.03887v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The advancement in Large Language Models has driven the creation of complex agentic systems, such as Deep Research Agents (DRAs), to overcome the limitations of static Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines in handling complex, multi-turn research tasks. This paper introduces the Static Deep Research Agent (Static-DRA), a novel solution built upon a configurable and hierarchical Tree-based static workflow. The core contribution is the integration of two user-tunable parameters, Depth and Breadth, which provide granular control over the research intensity. This design allows end-users to consciously balance the desired quality and comprehensiveness of the research report against the associated computational cost of Large Language Model (LLM) interactions. The agent's architecture, comprising Supervisor, Independent, and Worker agents, facilitates effective multi-hop information retrieval and parallel sub-topic investigation. We evaluate the Static-DRA against the established DeepResearch Bench using the RACE (Reference-based Adaptive Criteria-driven Evaluation) framework. Configured with a depth of 2 and a breadth of 5, and powered by the gemini-2.5-pro model, the agent achieved an overall score of 34.72. Our experiments validate that increasing the configured Depth and Breadth parameters results in a more in-depth research process and a correspondingly higher evaluation score. The Static-DRA offers a pragmatic and resource-aware solution, empowering users with transparent control over the deep research process. The entire source code, outputs and benchmark results are open-sourced at https://github.com/SauravP97/Static-Deep-Research/

item.title: Autonomous Agents and Policy Compliance: A Framework for Reasoning About Penalties
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: policy-aware agents, logic programming, penalties, Answer Set Programming, non-compliance

Summary:

This paper introduces a novel logic programming framework designed for autonomous agents that are policy-aware and capable of reasoning about penalties associated with non-compliance. Unlike prior efforts that mainly focused on ensuring strict policy adherence, this framework acknowledges scenarios where breaching policies might be necessary to achieve critical objectives. By modeling non-compliant behavior, it also aids policymakers in realistically simulating human decision-making processes. The framework extends the existing Authorization and Obligation Policy Language (AOPL) by incorporating penalty mechanisms and integrates Answer Set Programming (ASP) to facilitate sophisticated reasoning. Key enhancements over previous approaches include ensuring well-formed policies, managing policy priorities, and improving explainability by explicitly identifying rule violations and their consequences. Building on prior work by Harders and Inclezan, the framework introduces penalty-based reasoning to differentiate between non-compliant plans, favoring those with the least repercussions. It features an automated translation from the extended AOPL to ASP and refines ASP-based planning algorithms to consider incurred penalties. Experimental evaluations across two domains demonstrate the framework’s ability to generate higher-quality plans that minimize harmful actions while occasionally improving computational efficiency. These results highlight the framework’s potential to advance autonomous decision-making and support policy refinement efforts.
arXiv:2512.03931v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper presents a logic programming-based framework for policy-aware autonomous agents that can reason about potential penalties for non-compliance and act accordingly. While prior work has primarily focused on ensuring compliance, our approach considers scenarios where deviating from policies may be necessary to achieve high-stakes goals. Additionally, modeling non-compliant behavior can assist policymakers by simulating realistic human decision-making. Our framework extends Gelfond and Lobo's Authorization and Obligation Policy Language (AOPL) to incorporate penalties and integrates Answer Set Programming (ASP) for reasoning. Compared to previous approaches, our method ensures well-formed policies, accounts for policy priorities, and enhances explainability by explicitly identifying rule violations and their consequences. Building on the work of Harders and Inclezan, we introduce penalty-based reasoning to distinguish between non-compliant plans, prioritizing those with minimal repercussions. To support this, we develop an automated translation from the extended AOPL into ASP and refine ASP-based planning algorithms to account for incurred penalties. Experiments in two domains demonstrate that our framework generates higher-quality plans that avoid harmful actions while, in some cases, also improving computational efficiency. These findings underscore its potential for enhancing autonomous decision-making and informing policy refinement. Under consideration in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP).

item.title: Benchmark for Planning and Control with Large Language Model Agents: Blocksworld with Model Context Protocol
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Industrial automation, Large Language Models, Blocksworld benchmark, Model Context Protocol, adaptive planning

Summary:

1. The article addresses the growing need for flexible and adaptive control strategies in industrial automation that can adjust to varying tasks and dynamic environments.
2. It explores the potential of agents powered by Large Language Models (LLMs) for planning and execution tasks but highlights the absence of standardized benchmarks to evaluate and compare these agents systematically.
3. To fill this gap, the authors introduce a benchmark based on an executable simulation environment modeled around the Blocksworld problem, which is categorized into five levels of complexity to test agent performance under varying difficulty.
4. The benchmark incorporates the Model Context Protocol (MCP) as a uniform tool interface, allowing diverse agent architectures to connect with and be evaluated by the benchmark without requiring agent-specific modifications, promoting consistency and interoperability.
5. A proof-of-concept single-agent implementation is provided to demonstrate the benchmark's practical use, along with quantitative metrics designed to facilitate comparative evaluation of LLM-based planning and execution approaches within this context.
arXiv:2512.03955v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Industrial automation increasingly requires flexible control strategies that can adapt to changing tasks and environments. Agents based on Large Language Models (LLMs) offer potential for such adaptive planning and execution but lack standardized benchmarks for systematic comparison. We introduce a benchmark with an executable simulation environment representing the Blocksworld problem providing five complexity categories. By integrating the Model Context Protocol (MCP) as a standardized tool interface, diverse agent architectures can be connected to and evaluated against the benchmark without implementation-specific modifications. A single-agent implementation demonstrates the benchmark's applicability, establishing quantitative metrics for comparison of LLM-based planning and execution approaches.

item.title: AI-Driven Document Redaction in UK Public Authorities: Implementation Gaps, Regulatory Challenges, and the Human Oversight Imperative
item.content:encoded:
Document redaction, AI adoption, public authorities, Freedom of Information, data protection

Summary:

This study explores the adoption of AI-driven document redaction within UK public authorities by examining responses from 44 bodies across healthcare, government, and higher education sectors. It highlights that despite the potential of AI to enhance redaction processes, actual usage remains minimal, with only one authority reporting the use of AI tools. The research reveals significant organizational challenges, including a lack of formal redaction policies—with half of the authorities responding that relevant information was not held—and inadequate staff training on redaction practices. Three primary barriers to effective AI implementation are identified: poor record-keeping which hampers efficient information management, absence of standardized redaction guidelines leading to inconsistent practices, and insufficient specialized training for staff to oversee AI-driven processes properly. These findings underline the necessity of a socio-technical approach, combining technological automation with strong human expertise, to address both transparency and data protection requirements effectively. This study offers the first empirical assessment focused on AI redaction in UK public administration, providing valuable insights for policymakers tasked with balancing openness, privacy, and the integration of emerging AI technologies in public sector workflows.
arXiv:2512.02774v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Document redaction in public authorities faces critical challenges as traditional manual approaches struggle to balance growing transparency demands with increasingly stringent data protection requirements. This study investigates the implementation of AI-driven document redaction within UK public authorities through Freedom of Information (FOI) requests. While AI technologies offer potential solutions to redaction challenges, their actual implementation within public sector organizations remains underexplored. Based on responses from 44 public authorities across healthcare, government, and higher education sectors, this study reveals significant gaps between technological possibilities and organizational realities. Findings show highly limited AI adoption (only one authority reported using AI tools), widespread absence of formal redaction policies (50 percent reported "information not held"), and deficiencies in staff training. The study identifies three key barriers to effective AI implementation: poor record-keeping practices, lack of standardized redaction guidelines, and insufficient specialized training for human oversight. These findings highlight the need for a socio-technical approach that balances technological automation with meaningful human expertise. This research provides the first empirical assessment of AI redaction practices in UK public authorities and contributes evidence to support policymakers navigating the complex interplay between transparency obligations, data protection requirements, and emerging AI technologies in public administration.

item.title: Entropy-Based Measurement of Value Drift and Alignment Work in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, ethical entropy, alignment, value drift, dynamic safety

Summary: This article addresses the dynamic challenges in assessing the safety of large language models (LLMs), focusing on failures such as value drift under distribution shifts, jailbreak attacks, and gradual misalignment over deployment time. The authors build upon a conceptual framework called the Second Law of Intelligence, which models ethical entropy as a state variable that naturally tends to increase unless actively counteracted by alignment efforts. They operationalize this theory for LLMs by defining a five-way behavioral taxonomy and training a classifier capable of estimating ethical entropy S(t) based on model-generated transcripts. Their experiments measure entropy dynamics in both base and instruction-tuned versions of four leading LLMs subjected to various stress tests. Results reveal that base models exhibit sustained increases in ethical entropy, indicating growing misalignment, while instruction-tuned models effectively suppress this drift, reducing entropy by approximately 80%. From these entropy trajectories, the authors calculate an effective alignment work rate (γ_eff), which quantifies the effort required to maintain alignment. Finally, they integrate S(t) and γ_eff into a real-time monitoring pipeline that triggers alerts when entropy drift surpasses a defined stability threshold, enabling continuous oversight of LLM value alignment during deployment.
arXiv:2512.03047v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Large language model safety is usually assessed with static benchmarks, but key failures are dynamic: value drift under distribution shift, jailbreak attacks, and slow degradation of alignment in deployment. Building on a recent Second Law of Intelligence that treats ethical entropy as a state variable which tends to increase unless countered by alignment work, we make this framework operational for large language models. We define a five-way behavioral taxonomy, train a classifier to estimate ethical entropy S(t) from model transcripts, and measure entropy dynamics for base and instruction-tuned variants of four frontier models across stress tests. Base models show sustained entropy growth, while tuned variants suppress drift and reduce ethical entropy by roughly eighty percent. From these trajectories we estimate an effective alignment work rate gamma_eff and embed S(t) and gamma_eff in a monitoring pipeline that raises alerts when entropy drift exceeds a stability threshold, enabling run-time oversight of value drift.

item.title: Mitigating hallucinations and omissions in LLMs for invertible problems: An application to hardware logic design automation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: invertible problems, Large Language Models, Logic Condition Tables, Hardware Description Language, lossless encoding

Summary:
1. The paper addresses invertible problems where data can be transformed bidirectionally between a source domain (e.g., Logic Condition Tables - LCTs) and a destination domain (e.g., Hardware Description Language - HDL code).
2. It proposes using Large Language Models (LLMs) as lossless encoders and decoders, effectively transforming source data to destination data and back without information loss, analogous to lossless compression in information theory.
3. The method aims to mitigate common LLM issues such as hallucinations (fabricated content) and omissions by ensuring the fidelity of the data transformation.
4. Experimentally, LCTs are used as input to generate the full HDL description of a two-dimensional network-on-chip router (comprising 13 units and 1500-2000 lines of code) using seven different LLMs.
5. The HDL code is then decoded back to LCTs, and the original and reconstructed LCTs are compared for accuracy, confirming correct generation, detecting errors in LLM output, and helping developers identify specification errors, leading to significant productivity improvements.
arXiv:2512.03053v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We show for invertible problems that transform data from a source domain (for example, Logic Condition Tables (LCTs)) to a destination domain (for example, Hardware Description Language (HDL) code), an approach of using Large Language Models (LLMs) as a lossless encoder from source to destination followed by as a lossless decoder back to the source, comparable to lossless compression in information theory, can mitigate most of the LLM drawbacks of hallucinations and omissions. Specifically, using LCTs as inputs, we generate the full HDL for a two-dimensional network-on-chip router (13 units, 1500-2000 lines of code) using seven different LLMs, reconstruct the LCTs from the auto-generated HDL, and compare the original and reconstructed LCTs. This approach yields significant productivity improvements, not only confirming correctly generated LLM logic and detecting incorrectly generated LLM logic but also assisting developers in finding design specification errors.

item.title: Energy-Efficient Federated Learning via Adaptive Encoder Freezing for MRI-to-CT Conversion: A Green AI-Guided Research
item.content:encoded:
Federated Learning, Green AI, adaptive layer-freezing, MRI-to-CT conversion, energy efficiency

Summary:

Federated Learning (FL) enables diverse healthcare institutions to collaboratively train deep learning models without sharing data, potentially reducing healthcare disparities. However, the high computational and energy costs of FL often exclude centers with limited resources, exacerbating inequality. To address this, the authors propose a Green AI-inspired adaptive layer-freezing strategy that reduces energy consumption and computational load while preserving model performance. This method selectively freezes encoder weights in the federated model based on monitoring the relative weight changes between training rounds, with a patience mechanism ensuring freezing only when updates remain consistently small. The approach was tested on multiple FL architectures for MRI-to-CT image conversion tasks. Using the CodeCarbon library, the study tracked energy usage and CO2 emissions, finding that the adaptive freezing strategy reduced training time, total energy consumption, and CO2 equivalent emissions by up to 23% compared to non-frozen baselines. Importantly, MRI-to-CT conversion performance remained largely unaffected, with minimal variations in Mean Absolute Error; three out of five architectures showed no statistically significant performance change, while two showed improvements. This work supports the development of sustainable, equitable, and privacy-preserving AI frameworks in healthcare, laying a foundation for future FL evaluation methods aligned with clinical and environmental priorities.
arXiv:2512.03054v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Federated Learning (FL) holds the potential to advance equality in health by enabling diverse institutions to collaboratively train deep learning (DL) models, even with limited data. However, the significant resource requirements of FL often exclude centres with limited computational infrastructure, further widening existing healthcare disparities. To address this issue, we propose a Green AI-oriented adaptive layer-freezing strategy designed to reduce energy consumption and computational load while maintaining model performance. We tested our approach using different federated architectures for Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)-to-Computed Tomography (CT) conversion. The proposed adaptive strategy optimises the federated training by selectively freezing the encoder weights based on the monitored relative difference of the encoder weights from round to round. A patience-based mechanism ensures that freezing only occurs when updates remain consistently minimal. The energy consumption and CO2eq emissions of the federation were tracked using the CodeCarbon library. Compared to equivalent non-frozen counterparts, our approach reduced training time, total energy consumption and CO2eq emissions by up to 23%. At the same time, the MRI-to-CT conversion performance was maintained, with only small variations in the Mean Absolute Error (MAE). Notably, for three out of the five evaluated architectures, no statistically significant differences were observed, while two architectures exhibited statistically significant improvements. Our work aligns with a research paradigm that promotes DL-based frameworks meeting clinical requirements while ensuring climatic, social, and economic sustainability. It lays the groundwork for novel FL evaluation frameworks, advancing privacy, equity and, more broadly, justice in AI-driven healthcare.

item.title: Physics-informed self-supervised learning for predictive modeling of coronary artery digital twins
item.content:encoded:
Cardiovascular disease, coronary artery disease, physics-informed learning, graph neural networks, fractional flow reserve

Summary:
1. Cardiovascular disease, particularly coronary artery disease (CAD), is the leading cause of death worldwide, underscoring the need for early risk prediction. 2. Conventional analysis of 3D coronary artery digital twins reconstructed from imaging requires computationally intensive computational fluid dynamics (CFD), which limits scalability. 3. Data-driven methods are challenged by limited labeled data and absence of physiological prior knowledge, restricting their effectiveness. 4. The study introduces PINS-CAD, a physics-informed self-supervised learning framework that pre-trains graph neural networks on 200,000 synthetic coronary artery digital twins using 1D Navier-Stokes equations and pressure-drop laws, removing reliance on CFD and labeled data. 5. When fine-tuned on clinical data from 635 patients in the FAME2 multicenter study, PINS-CAD predicts future cardiovascular events with an AUC of 0.73, outperforming conventional clinical risk scores and other data-driven models. 6. PINS-CAD produces spatially resolved pressure and fractional flow reserve curves, offering interpretable biomarkers linked to physiological function. 7. By integrating physical priors into geometric deep learning, PINS-CAD enables simulation-free, physiology-aware analysis of routine angiography, enhancing scalability and preventive cardiology applications.
arXiv:2512.03055v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Cardiovascular disease is the leading global cause of mortality, with coronary artery disease (CAD) as its most prevalent form, necessitating early risk prediction. While 3D coronary artery digital twins reconstructed from imaging offer detailed anatomy for personalized assessment, their analysis relies on computationally intensive computational fluid dynamics (CFD), limiting scalability. Data-driven approaches are hindered by scarce labeled data and lack of physiological priors. To address this, we present PINS-CAD, a physics-informed self-supervised learning framework. It pre-trains graph neural networks on 200,000 synthetic coronary digital twins to predict pressure and flow, guided by 1D Navier-Stokes equations and pressure-drop laws, eliminating the need for CFD or labeled data. When fine-tuned on clinical data from 635 patients in the multicenter FAME2 study, PINS-CAD predicts future cardiovascular events with an AUC of 0.73, outperforming clinical risk scores and data-driven baselines. This demonstrates that physics-informed pretraining boosts sample efficiency and yields physiologically meaningful representations. Furthermore, PINS-CAD generates spatially resolved pressure and fractional flow reserve curves, providing interpretable biomarkers. By embedding physical priors into geometric deep learning, PINS-CAD transforms routine angiography into a simulation-free, physiology-aware framework for scalable, preventive cardiology.

item.title: Delta Sampling: Data-Free Knowledge Transfer Across Diffusion Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Diffusion Models, Stable Diffusion, Knowledge Transfer, Delta Sampling, Image Synthesis

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of adapting diffusion models, specifically Stable Diffusion (SD), when upgrading base models with significant architectural changes, such as moving from SD 1.x to 2.x. Existing adaptation components like LoRA, LyCORIS, and ControlNet are tightly coupled to a specific base model version, limiting their reusability across different versions. The authors propose Delta Sampling (DS), a novel inference-time method that enables knowledge transfer across base models with differing architectures without needing access to the original training data. DS leverages the delta, defined as the difference in model predictions before and after adaptation on the original base model, to guide the denoising process in the new base model. This approach effectively retains the desired adaptation effects, including visual styles, semantic concepts, and structures. The effectiveness of DS is demonstrated through evaluations across various versions of Stable Diffusion and under different sampling strategies. Results indicate that DS consistently improves the transferability of adaptation components and can be used as a plug-and-play mechanism for cross-model knowledge transfer in diffusion-based image synthesis. The method enhances model flexibility and prolongs the usability of existing fine-tuned components amid model upgrades. Code for DS is publicly available.
arXiv:2512.03056v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Diffusion models like Stable Diffusion (SD) drive a vibrant open-source ecosystem including fully fine-tuned checkpoints and parameter-efficient adapters such as LoRA, LyCORIS, and ControlNet. However, these adaptation components are tightly coupled to a specific base model, making them difficult to reuse when the base model is upgraded (e.g., from SD 1.x to 2.x) due to substantial changes in model parameters and architecture. In this work, we propose Delta Sampling (DS), a novel method that enables knowledge transfer across base models with different architectures, without requiring access to the original training data. DS operates entirely at inference time by leveraging the delta: the difference in model predictions before and after the adaptation of a base model. This delta is then used to guide the denoising process of a new base model. We evaluate DS across various SD versions, demonstrating that DS achieves consistent improvements in creating desired effects (e.g., visual styles, semantic concepts, and structures) under different sampling strategies. These results highlight DS as an effective, plug-and-play mechanism for knowledge transfer in diffusion-based image synthesis. Code:~ https://github.com/Zhidong-Gao/DeltaSampling

item.title: A note on the impossibility of conditional PAC-efficient reasoning in large language models
item.content:encoded:
conditional PAC efficiency, large language models, impossibility result, expert model deferral, non-atomic input spaces

Summary:

1. The paper establishes an impossibility result regarding conditional Probably Approximately Correct (PAC)-efficient reasoning in large language models. 2. While previous work demonstrated marginal PAC efficiency guarantees for models that dynamically switch between expensive expert models and cheaper fast models, this study focuses on conditional (pointwise) PAC guarantees. 3. The authors prove that such conditional PAC efficiency guarantees cannot be achieved in a distribution-free setting, especially for input spaces that are non-atomic. 4. The impossibility result implies that any algorithm aiming for conditional PAC efficiency must behave trivially by relying heavily on the expensive expert model; specifically, it must defer to the expert with probability at least 1−α for almost every input. 5. This finding highlights a fundamental limitation in designing composite reasoning systems that aim to be both efficient and provide strong conditional performance guarantees across all inputs without assumptions on the input distribution.
arXiv:2512.03057v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We prove an impossibility result for conditional Probably Approximately Correct (PAC)-efficient reasoning in large language models. While recent work has established marginal PAC efficiency guarantees for composite models that switch between expensive expert models and cheaper fast models, we show that conditional (pointwise) guarantees are impossible in the distribution-free setting. Specifically, for non-atomic input spaces, any algorithm achieving conditional PAC efficiency must be trivial in the sense that it defers to the expert model with probability at least $1-\alpha$ for almost every input.

item.title: Optimizing Life Sciences Agents in Real-Time using Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Generative AI, Thompson Sampling, Contextual Bandits, Life Sciences, User Feedback

Summary:

This article addresses the challenge faced by generative AI agents in life sciences, which must handle a wide variety of queries from simple fact-based questions to complex mechanistic reasoning. Traditional approaches relying on fixed rules or costly labeled training data lack adaptability to evolving conditions or user preferences. The authors propose a novel framework combining AWS Strands Agents with Thompson Sampling contextual bandits, enabling AI agents to learn optimal decision-making strategies solely from user feedback. Their system optimizes three key dimensions simultaneously: generation strategy selection (choosing between direct answers or chain-of-thought processes), tool selection (leveraging resources like literature searches and drug databases), and domain routing (directing queries to specialists in pharmacology, molecular biology, or clinical fields). Empirical evaluation on life science queries shows a significant 15-30% increase in user satisfaction compared to random baseline methods. Notably, the system demonstrates clear learning patterns emerging after 20-30 user interactions. Importantly, this approach requires no ground truth labels, allowing continuous adaptation to user preferences.
