1. The article addresses the global challenge of providing equitable and universal access to quality education and sees generative AI (gen AI) as a promising tool to offer personalized tutoring and teaching assistance.

2. Despite initial enthusiasm, the full potential of gen AI in education remains unrealized primarily due to difficulties in expressing pedagogical principles effectively in AI prompts and the absence of robust evaluation methods.

3. The authors collaborate with learners and educators to translate learning science principles into a practical framework consisting of seven diverse educational benchmarks, which include quantitative, qualitative, automatic, and human evaluations.

4. To enhance pedagogical capabilities, the study introduces LearnLM-Tutor, a fine-tuned version of the Gemini model, supported by new fine-tuning datasets.

5. Evaluations reveal that LearnLM-Tutor is consistently preferred by educators and learners across multiple pedagogical dimensions compared to prompt-tuned Gemini.

The work aims to initiate the development of a comprehensive evaluation framework in education AI, fostering rapid advancements to maximize generative AI's beneficial impact in educational settings.
arXiv:2407.12687v4 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: A major challenge facing the world is the provision of equitable and universal access to quality education. Recent advances in generative AI (gen AI) have created excitement about the potential of new technologies to offer a personal tutor for every learner and a teaching assistant for every teacher. The full extent of this dream, however, has not yet materialised. We argue that this is primarily due to the difficulties with verbalising pedagogical intuitions into gen AI prompts and the lack of good evaluation practices, reinforced by the challenges in defining excellent pedagogy. Here we present our work collaborating with learners and educators to translate high level principles from learning science into a pragmatic set of seven diverse educational benchmarks, spanning quantitative, qualitative, automatic and human evaluations; and to develop a new set of fine-tuning datasets to improve the pedagogical capabilities of Gemini, introducing LearnLM-Tutor. Our evaluations show that LearnLM-Tutor is consistently preferred over a prompt tuned Gemini by educators and learners on a number of pedagogical dimensions. We hope that this work can serve as a first step towards developing a comprehensive educational evaluation framework, and that this can enable rapid progress within the AI and EdTech communities towards maximising the positive impact of gen AI in education.

item.title: The 4/$\delta$ Bound: Designing Predictable LLM-Verifier Systems for Formal Method Guarantee
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Formal Verification, Large Language Models, Convergence Theorem, Markov Chain, Verification Termination

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of integrating Formal Verification with Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve software verification workflows, which currently lack reliability and theoretical guarantees. It introduces the LLM-Verifier Convergence Theorem, a novel theoretical framework that models the interaction between LLM and verifier as a discrete-time Markov Chain governed by an error-reduction probability parameter, δ. The theorem guarantees that the verification process will almost surely reach a verified state, ensuring termination and convergence for any δ greater than zero. Additionally, the expected number of iterations needed to verify is bounded by 4/δ. The authors validated these theoretical predictions through an extensive empirical study with over 90,000 trials, confirming that every run achieved verification and the convergence factor was tightly clustered around 1.0, closely aligning with the theoretical bound. Based on these findings, the workflow can be confidently divided into three operational zones—marginal, practical, and high-performance—providing a clear architectural basis for system design and parameter tuning. This work enables more predictable resource planning and performance budgeting, facilitating safer deployment of LLM-assisted verification systems in safety-critical environments.

arXiv:2512.02080v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The idea of using Formal Verification tools with large language models (LLMs) has enabled scaling software verification beyond manual workflows. However, current methods remain unreliable. Without a solid theoretical footing, the refinement process can wander; sometimes it settles, sometimes it loops back, and sometimes it breaks away from any stable trajectory. This work bridges this critical gap by developing an LLM-Verifier Convergence Theorem, providing the first formal framework with provable guarantees for termination and convergence. We model the interaction between the LLM and the verifier as a discrete-time Markov Chain, with state transitions determined by a key parameter: the error-reduction probability ($\delta$). The procedure reaching the Verified state almost surely demonstrates that the program terminates for any $\delta > 0$, with an expected iteration count bounded by $\mathbb{E}[n] \leq 4/\delta$. We then stress-tested this prediction in an extensive empirical campaign comprising more than 90,000 trials. The empirical results match the theory with striking consistency. Every single run reached verification, and the convergence factor clustered tightly around $C_f\approx$ 1.0. Consequently, the bound mirrors the system's actual behavior. The evidence is sufficiently robust to support dividing the workflow into three distinct operating zones: marginal, practical, and high-performance. Consequently, we establish the design thresholds with absolute confidence. Together, the theoretical guarantee and the experimental evidence provide a clearer architectural foundation for LLM-assisted verification. Heuristic tuning no longer has to be carried out by the system. Engineers gain a framework that supports predictable resource planning and performance budgeting, precisely what is needed before deploying these pipelines into safety-critical software environments.

item.title: Flowchart2Mermaid: A Vision-Language Model Powered System for Converting Flowcharts into Editable Diagram Code
item.content:encoded:
Flowchart conversion, Mermaid.js, vision-language models, AI-assisted editing, evaluation metrics

Summary: The paper introduces Flowchart2Mermaid, a lightweight web-based system designed to transform static flowchart images into editable Mermaid.js code, a markup language specialized for visual workflows. The system leverages detailed system prompts and vision-language models to accurately interpret and convert graphical content into structured textual representations. Unlike traditional image-to-diagram conversion tools, Flowchart2Mermaid ensures that the generated code remains synchronized with the rendered diagram and supports version control. The interface features mixed-initiative refinement capabilities that enable users to edit flowcharts interactively through inline text editing, drag-and-drop node insertion, and natural language commands interpreted by an integrated AI assistant. This design facilitates iterative improvements and customization of diagrams without losing structural integrity. Additionally, the authors propose new evaluation metrics to comprehensively assess the performance of multiple models in terms of structural accuracy, flow correctness, syntax validity, and completeness. These metrics provide a more rigorous framework for benchmarking and improving diagram conversion tools. Overall, Flowchart2Mermaid advances the usability and flexibility of flowchart editing by bridging static images and dynamic, code-based workflow representations.
arXiv:2512.02170v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Flowcharts are common tools for communicating processes but are often shared as static images that cannot be easily edited or reused. We present \textsc{Flowchart2Mermaid}, a lightweight web system that converts flowchart images into editable Mermaid.js code which is a markup language for visual workflows, using a detailed system prompt and vision-language models. The interface supports mixed-initiative refinement through inline text editing, drag-and-drop node insertion, and natural-language commands interpreted by an integrated AI assistant. Unlike prior image-to-diagram tools, our approach produces a structured, version-controllable textual representation that remains synchronized with the rendered diagram. We further introduce evaluation metrics to assess structural accuracy, flow correctness, syntax validity, and completeness across multiple models.

item.title: From monoliths to modules: Decomposing transducers for efficient world modelling
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: world models, transducers, modularity, decomposition, AI safety

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of efficiently modeling complex world environments for AI agents by leveraging modular structures inherent in real-world scenarios.
2. It focuses on world models represented by transducers, which generalize Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (POMDPs), offering a flexible and powerful modelling approach.
3. While the composition of transducers into larger systems is well understood, this work innovates by proposing a method to invert this process, effectively decomposing monolithic transducers into smaller sub-transducers.
4. These sub-transducers operate on distinct input-output subspaces, enabling parallel processing and enhancing model interpretability.
5. The modular decomposition framework supports distributed inference, improving computational efficiency without sacrificing structural transparency, which is crucial for AI safety.
6. Overall, this approach bridges the gap between the demands for transparency in AI safety and the practical requirements of computational efficiency for real-world deployment.
arXiv:2512.02193v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: World models have been recently proposed as sandbox environments in which AI agents can be trained and evaluated before deployment. Although realistic world models often have high computational demands, efficient modelling is usually possible by exploiting the fact that real-world scenarios tend to involve subcomponents that interact in a modular manner. In this paper, we explore this idea by developing a framework for decomposing complex world models represented by transducers, a class of models generalising POMDPs. Whereas the composition of transducers is well understood, our results clarify how to invert this process, deriving sub-transducers operating on distinct input-output subspaces, enabling parallelizable and interpretable alternatives to monolithic world modelling that can support distributed inference. Overall, these results lay a groundwork for bridging the structural transparency demanded by AI safety and the computational efficiency required for real-world inference.

item.title: STRIDE: A Systematic Framework for Selecting AI Modalities - Agentic AI, AI Assistants, or LLM Calls
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: autonomous agents, large language models, task modality selection, STRIDE framework, agentic suitability score

Summary: The article addresses the challenge of determining when to deploy autonomous, goal-driven AI agents as opposed to simpler interaction modalities with large language models (LLMs). It introduces STRIDE, a novel framework designed to evaluate task requirements systematically to recommend the most appropriate AI modality among direct LLM calls, guided AI assistants, and fully autonomous agents. STRIDE operates by analyzing structured task decomposition, task dynamism, and the need for self-reflection to generate an Agentic Suitability Score. This score helps reserve full agentic autonomy exclusively for tasks involving dynamic or evolving contexts, thereby reducing unnecessary complexity. The framework was extensively evaluated on 30 real-world tasks within site reliability engineering (SRE), compliance, and enterprise automation, achieving 92% accuracy in selecting the correct modality. STRIDE also led to a 45% reduction in redundant agent deployments and a 37% decrease in resource costs. Additionally, a six-month expert validation phase with domain specialists confirmed the framework's effectiveness and practicality. Overall, the work advocates for a necessity-driven approach to deploying agentic AI, emphasizing cost-benefit alignment and responsible adoption tailored to the intrinsic needs of the task.
arXiv:2512.02228v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid shift from stateless large language models (LLMs) to autonomous, goal-driven agents raises a central question: When is agentic AI truly necessary? While agents enable multi-step reasoning, persistent memory, and tool orchestration, deploying them indiscriminately leads to higher cost, complexity, and risk. We present STRIDE (Systematic Task Reasoning Intelligence Deployment Evaluator), a framework that provides principled recommendations for selecting between three modalities: (i) direct LLM calls, (ii) guided AI assistants, and (iii) fully autonomous agentic AI. STRIDE integrates structured task decomposition, dynamism attribution, and self-reflection requirement analysis to produce an Agentic Suitability Score, ensuring that full agentic autonomy is reserved for tasks with inherent dynamism or evolving context. Evaluated across 30 real-world tasks spanning SRE, compliance, and enterprise automation, STRIDE achieved 92% accuracy in modality selection, reduced unnecessary agent deployments by 45%, and cut resource costs by 37%. Expert validation over six months in SRE and compliance domains confirmed its practical utility, with domain specialists agreeing that STRIDE effectively distinguishes between tasks requiring simple LLM calls, guided assistants, or full agentic autonomy. This work reframes agent adoption as a necessity-driven design decision, ensuring autonomy is applied only when its benefits justify the costs.

item.title: Benchmarking LLM Agents for Wealth-Management Workflows
item.content:encoded:
finance, LLM agent, wealth management, evaluation benchmark, task automation

Summary:

This dissertation expands TheAgentCompany framework by creating a finance-centered environment aimed at testing whether a general-purpose large language model (LLM) agent can perform wealth-management tasks effectively and economically. It introduces synthetic domain-specific data and enhances simulations of colleague interactions to build realism. An automatic task-generation pipeline is prototyped to systematically produce and evaluate diverse tasks. The study develops a benchmark comprising 12 paired wealth management tasks covering retrieval, analysis, synthesis, and communication, each equipped with explicit acceptance criteria and deterministic grading to objectively assess agent performance. The benchmark distinguishes between high-autonomy and low-autonomy versions of each task to investigate how autonomy impacts task execution and outcomes. Results show that the main limitation of agents lies not in mathematical reasoning ability but in the reliability of end-to-end workflow completion. Furthermore, autonomy level significantly affects agent performance, with higher autonomy introducing more challenges. The study also highlights problems caused by improper model evaluation practices, which have obstructed accurate benchmarking in this domain. Overall, this research provides new tools, data, and insights necessary to evaluate and improve LLM agents for assistant-level wealth management tasks.
arXiv:2512.02230v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Modern work relies on an assortment of digital collaboration tools, yet routine processes continue to suffer from human error and delay. To address this gap, this dissertation extends TheAgentCompany with a finance-focused environment and investigates whether a general purpose LLM agent can complete representative wealth-management tasks both accurately and economically. This study introduces synthetic domain data, enriches colleague simulations, and prototypes an automatic task-generation pipeline. The study aims to create and assess an evaluation set that can meaningfully measure an agent's fitness for assistant-level wealth management work. We construct a benchmark of 12 task-pairs for wealth management assistants spanning retrieval, analysis, and synthesis/communication, with explicit acceptance criteria and deterministic graders. We seeded a set of new finance-specific data and introduced a high vs. low-autonomy variant of every task. The paper concluded that agents are limited less by mathematical reasoning and more so by end-to-end workflow reliability, and meaningfully affected by autonomy level, and that incorrect evaluation of models have hindered benchmarking.

item.title: TradeTrap: Are LLM-based Trading Agents Truly Reliable and Faithful?
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: autonomous trading agents, robustness evaluation, adversarial perturbations, financial markets, backtesting framework

Summary:
1. The paper addresses the increasing deployment of Large Language Model (LLM)-based autonomous trading agents in real-world financial markets, highlighting the need to assess their reliability under adverse or faulty conditions.
2. The authors introduce TradeTrap, a comprehensive evaluation framework designed to systematically stress-test both adaptive and procedural trading agents by inducing controlled perturbations at the system level.
3. TradeTrap focuses on four critical components of autonomous trading agents: market intelligence, strategy formulation, portfolio and ledger management, and trade execution, to evaluate their robustness against disruptions.
4. Evaluations are performed using a closed-loop backtesting environment with real US equity market data, maintaining identical initial conditions to ensure consistent and reproducible comparisons across different agents and attack scenarios.
5. Experimental results demonstrate that even minor disturbances targeting a single component can propagate throughout the decision-making process, causing severe issues such as portfolio concentration, runaway exposure, and significant drawdowns, revealing vulnerabilities in current autonomous trading agents.
6. The authors also provide open access to their code repository, facilitating further research and development in robust autonomous trading systems.
arXiv:2512.02261v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: LLM-based trading agents are increasingly deployed in real-world financial markets to perform autonomous analysis and execution. However, their reliability and robustness under adversarial or faulty conditions remain largely unexamined, despite operating in high-risk, irreversible financial environments. We propose TradeTrap, a unified evaluation framework for systematically stress-testing both adaptive and procedural autonomous trading agents. TradeTrap targets four core components of autonomous trading agents: market intelligence, strategy formulation, portfolio and ledger handling, and trade execution, and evaluates their robustness under controlled system-level perturbations. All evaluations are conducted in a closed-loop historical backtesting setting on real US equity market data with identical initial conditions, enabling fair and reproducible comparisons across agents and attacks. Extensive experiments show that small perturbations at a single component can propagate through the agent decision loop and induce extreme concentration, runaway exposure, and large portfolio drawdowns across both agent types, demonstrating that current autonomous trading agents can be systematically misled at the system level. Our code is available at https://github.com/Yanlewen/TradeTrap.

item.title: Bridging the Gap: Toward Cognitive Autonomy in Artificial Intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI limitations, self-monitoring, meta-cognition, cognitive autonomy, neurocognitive architecture

Summary: This paper examines seven fundamental limitations in contemporary AI systems that hinder their autonomous and adaptive capabilities: lack of intrinsic self-monitoring, deficient meta-cognitive awareness, rigid learning processes, inability to dynamically restructure goals, poor representational maintenance, limited embodied feedback, and absence of intrinsic agency. These shortcomings prevent current AI architectures, including deep learning and transformers, from achieving robust generalization, lifelong learning, and genuine autonomy in real-world environments. The authors argue that simply scaling up existing models cannot overcome these deficits. Instead, they propose a paradigm shift toward designing AI systems inspired by neurocognitive principles observed in biological cognition. Such cognitively grounded AI would enable self-directed adaptation, dynamic management of internal representations, and intentional, goal-oriented behavior. Additionally, the paper emphasizes integrating reformative oversight mechanisms to ensure these autonomous systems remain interpretable, governable, and aligned with human values. By drawing on insights from AI research, cognitive science, and neuroscience, the authors advocate developing architectures capable of cognitive autonomy, moving beyond current limitations toward more resilient, adaptive, and ethically guided AI systems.
arXiv:2512.02280v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Artificial intelligence has advanced rapidly across perception, language, reasoning, and multimodal domains. Yet despite these achievements, modern AI systems remain fun- damentally limited in their ability to self-monitor, self-correct, and regulate their behavior autonomously in dynamic contexts. This paper identifies and analyzes seven core deficiencies that constrain contemporary AI models: the absence of intrinsic self- monitoring, lack of meta-cognitive awareness, fixed and non- adaptive learning mechanisms, inability to restructure goals, lack of representational maintenance, insufficient embodied feedback, and the absence of intrinsic agency. Alongside identifying these limitations, we also outline a forward-looking perspective on how AI may evolve beyond them through architectures that mirror neurocognitive principles. We argue that these structural limitations prevent current architectures, including deep learning and transformer-based systems, from achieving robust general- ization, lifelong adaptability, and real-world autonomy. Drawing on a comparative analysis of artificial systems and biological cognition [7], and integrating insights from AI research, cognitive science, and neuroscience, we outline how these capabilities are absent in current models and why scaling alone cannot resolve them. We conclude by advocating for a paradigmatic shift toward cognitively grounded AI (cognitive autonomy) capable of self-directed adaptation, dynamic representation management, and intentional, goal-oriented behavior, paired with reformative oversight mechanisms [8] that ensure autonomous systems remain interpretable, governable, and aligned with human values.

item.title: DialogGuard: Multi-Agent Psychosocial Safety Evaluation of Sensitive LLM Responses
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large language models, psychosocial safety, multi-agent framework, DialogGuard, risk assessment

Summary: This paper introduces DialogGuard, a novel multi-agent framework designed to assess psychosocial risks in responses generated by large language models (LLMs), particularly in sensitive contexts such as mental health and crisis intervention. It targets five critical dimensions of high-severity risks: privacy violations, discriminatory behavior, mental manipulation, psychological harm, and insulting behavior. DialogGuard operates through four distinct LLM-based judging pipelines—single-agent scoring, dual-agent correction, multi-agent debate, and stochastic majority voting—built upon a unified three-level rubric that is also accessible to human annotators. The framework is evaluated using the PKU-SafeRLHF dataset, which includes human safety annotations. Results indicate that multi-agent approaches outperform both single-agent judgments and traditional non-LLM baselines in accuracy. Among the approaches, dual-agent correction and majority voting strike the best balance between accuracy, alignment with human ratings, and robustness, while the debate method achieves higher recall but tends to flag more borderline cases excessively. DialogGuard is released as open-source software with a user-friendly web interface, providing detailed risk scores and natural language rationales per risk dimension. A formative study involving 12 practitioners demonstrates its effectiveness for prompt design, auditing, and supervision in web applications aimed at vulnerable user groups.
arXiv:2512.02282v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) now mediate many web-based mental- health, crisis, and other emotionally sensitive services, yet their psychosocial safety in these settings remains poorly understood and weakly evaluated. We present DialogGuard, a multi-agent frame- work for assessing psychosocial risks in LLM-generated responses along five high-severity dimensions: privacy violations, discrimi- natory behaviour, mental manipulation, psychological harm, and insulting behaviour. DialogGuard can be applied to diverse gen- erative models through four LLM-as-a-judge pipelines, including single-agent scoring, dual-agent correction, multi-agent debate, and stochastic majority voting, grounded in a shared three-level rubric usable by both human annotators and LLM judges. Using PKU-SafeRLHF with human safety annotations, we show that multi- agent mechanisms detect psychosocial risks more accurately than non-LLM baselines and single-agent judging; dual-agent correction and majority voting provide the best trade-off between accuracy, alignment with human ratings, and robustness, while debate attains higher recall but over-flags borderline cases. We release Dialog- Guard as open-source software with a web interface that provides per-dimension risk scores and explainable natural-language ratio- nales. A formative study with 12 practitioners illustrates how it supports prompt design, auditing, and supervision of web-facing applications for vulnerable users.

item.title: Model Recovery at the Edge under Resource Constraints for Physical AI
item.content:encoded:
Model Recovery, Neural ODEs, FPGA acceleration, Memory efficiency, Real-time MCAS

Summary:

1. The paper addresses Model Recovery (MR), which is essential for safe and explainable decision making in mission-critical autonomous systems (MCAS) by learning the underlying dynamical equations of the system.

2. Traditional MR approaches rely on neural ordinary differential equations (NODEs), which utilize iterative solvers that are inefficient on edge devices such as FPGAs, resulting in high memory and energy consumption.

3. The authors propose MERINDA, a novel FPGA-accelerated MR framework that replaces these iterative solvers with a parallelizable neural architecture functionally equivalent to NODEs, thereby enhancing efficiency.

4. Experimental results demonstrate that MERINDA reduces DRAM usage by nearly 11 times and achieves 2.2 times faster runtime compared to mobile GPUs, showcasing significant improvements in both memory and speed.

5. Additionally, experiments discover an inverse relationship between memory usage and energy consumption at fixed accuracy, highlighting MERINDA’s practical suitability for real-time, resource-constrained MCAS environments.
arXiv:2512.02283v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Model Recovery (MR) enables safe, explainable decision making in mission-critical autonomous systems (MCAS) by learning governing dynamical equations, but its deployment on edge devices is hindered by the iterative nature of neural ordinary differential equations (NODEs), which are inefficient on FPGAs. Memory and energy consumption are the main concerns when applying MR on edge devices for real-time operation. We propose MERINDA, a novel FPGA-accelerated MR framework that replaces iterative solvers with a parallelizable neural architecture equivalent to NODEs. MERINDA achieves nearly 11x lower DRAM usage and 2.2x faster runtime compared to mobile GPUs. Experiments reveal an inverse relationship between memory and energy at fixed accuracy, highlighting MERINDA's suitability for resource-constrained, real-time MCAS.

item.title: Breast Cell Segmentation Under Extreme Data Constraints: Quantum Enhancement Meets Adaptive Loss Stabilization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: breast cell segmentation, quantum-inspired edge enhancement, class imbalance, EfficientNet-B7/UNet++, weighted sampling

Summary:

1. The study tackles the time-consuming and expert-dependent process of annotating medical images, focusing on breast cell segmentation with minimal training data (599 images).

2. A novel quantum-inspired edge enhancement method using multi-scale Gabor filters creates an additional input channel, significantly improving boundary detection accuracy where annotator variability is high.

3. To address severe class imbalance—since breast tissue pixels are only 4% and epithelial cell areas 0.1%-20%—a stabilized multi-component loss function integrating adaptive Dice loss, boundary-aware terms, and automatic positive weighting is proposed.

4. A complexity-based weighted sampling strategy prioritizes difficult mammary epithelial regions, enhancing small lesion detection by 3.8%.

5. The model architecture combines EfficientNet-B7 with UNet++, using a channel projection strategy to leverage pretrained weights despite limited data.

6. Validation robustness is ensured by using exponential moving averaging and statistical outlier detection on a small validation set (129 images).

7. The framework achieves outstanding performance with a Dice score of 95.5% (±0.3%) and IoU of 91.2% (±0.4%), with quantum enhancement contributing a 2.1% gain in boundary accuracy.

8. Overall, this approach substantially reduces annotation effort and expert time, addressing a critical bottleneck in clinical AI analysis workflows.
arXiv:2512.02302v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Annotating medical images demands significant time and expertise, often requiring pathologists to invest hundreds of hours in labeling mammary epithelial nuclei datasets. We address this critical challenge by achieving 95.5% Dice score using just 599 training images for breast cell segmentation, where just 4% of pixels represent breast tissue and 60% of images contain no breast regions. Our framework uses quantum-inspired edge enhancement via multi-scale Gabor filters creating a fourth input channel, enhancing boundary detection where inter-annotator variations reach +/- 3 pixels. We present a stabilized multi-component loss function that integrates adaptive Dice loss with boundary-aware terms and automatic positive weighting to effectively address severe class imbalance, where mammary epithelial cell regions comprise only 0.1%-20% of the total image area. Additionally, a complexity-based weighted sampling strategy is introduced to prioritize the challenging mammary epithelial cell regions. The model employs an EfficientNet-B7/UNet++ architecture with a 4-to-3 channel projection, enabling the use of pretrained weights despite limited medical imaging data. Finally, robust validation is achieved through exponential moving averaging and statistical outlier detection, ensuring reliable performance estimates on a small validation set (129 images). Our framework achieves a Dice score of 95.5% +/- 0.3% and an IoU of 91.2% +/- 0.4%. Notably, quantum-based enhancement contributes to a 2.1% improvement in boundary accuracy, while weighted sampling increases small lesion detection by 3.8%. By achieving groundbreaking performance with limited annotations, our approach significantly reduces the medical expert time required for dataset creation, addressing a fundamental bottleneck in clinical perception AI development.

item.title: OmniGuard: Unified Omni-Modal Guardrails with Deliberate Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Omni-modal Large Language Models, safety guardrails, OmniGuard, multi-modal dataset, value alignment

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the challenge of ensuring safety and value alignment in Omni-modal Large Language Models (OLLMs) that process text, images, videos, and audio simultaneously. Existing guardrail research is mostly unimodal and often treats safety as a binary classification problem, which lacks robustness across diverse modalities and tasks.

2. The authors propose OmniGuard, the first comprehensive family of omni-modal safety guardrails designed to provide deliberate reasoning and safeguarding across all modalities. This system aims to unify policy enforcement and risk mitigation in multi-modal AI interactions.

3. To train OmniGuard effectively, they curate a large-scale, diverse omni-modal safety dataset comprising over 210,000 samples. These samples include unimodal and cross-modal inputs with structured safety labels and expert-model-generated safety critiques derived via targeted distillation.

4. Extensive evaluations are conducted on 15 different benchmarks encompassing varied multi-modal safety scenarios. Results demonstrate OmniGuard’s strong effectiveness and its ability to generalize safety across different modes of input.

5. The work pioneers a unified framework for omni-modal safeguarding, setting a foundation for building more robust, capable, and safe multi-modal AI systems that better align with human values and reduce risks in complex interactive settings.
arXiv:2512.02306v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Omni-modal Large Language Models (OLLMs) that process text, images, videos, and audio introduce new challenges for safety and value guardrails in human-AI interaction. Prior guardrail research largely targets unimodal settings and typically frames safeguarding as binary classification, which limits robustness across diverse modalities and tasks. To address this gap, we propose OmniGuard, the first family of omni-modal guardrails that performs safeguarding across all modalities with deliberate reasoning ability. To support the training of OMNIGUARD, we curate a large, comprehensive omni-modal safety dataset comprising over 210K diverse samples, with inputs that cover all modalities through both unimodal and cross-modal samples. Each sample is annotated with structured safety labels and carefully curated safety critiques from expert models through targeted distillation. Extensive experiments on 15 benchmarks show that OmniGuard achieves strong effectiveness and generalization across a wide range of multimodal safety scenarios. Importantly, OmniGuard provides a unified framework that enforces policies and mitigates risks in omni-modalities, paving the way toward building more robust and capable omnimodal safeguarding systems.

item.title: Reasoning Path and Latent State Analysis for Multi-view Visual Spatial Reasoning: A Cognitive Science Perspective
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: spatial reasoning, vision-language models, multi-view consistency, ReMindView-Bench, spatial cognition

Summary:
1. Spatial reasoning enables human perception, inference, and planning in 3D environments, but current vision-language models (VLMs) struggle with maintaining geometric coherence and cross-view consistency in multi-view settings. 2. The paper identifies a gap caused by a lack of fine-grained benchmarks that separate multi-view spatial reasoning from single-view perception and temporal influences. 3. To address this, the authors introduce ReMindView-Bench, a cognitively grounded benchmark designed to evaluate how VLMs build, align, and sustain spatial mental models across varying viewpoints, systematically varying spatial patterns and query types. 4. Evaluations on 15 existing VLMs demonstrate persistent failures in cross-view alignment and perspective-taking when reasoning across multiple views, emphasizing the need for deeper understanding of the reasoning process. 5. Using LLM-as-a-judge phase-wise analysis and self-consistency prompting, the study finds VLMs perform well on single-frame perception but significantly degrade when integrating information from multiple views. Additional probing and entropy analyses reveal a progressive loss of task-relevant information and weakened discrimination between correct and incorrect reasoning trajectories. 6. These findings provide a cognitively grounded diagnosis of how multi-view spatial mental models are constructed, deteriorate, and destabilize during reasoning phases. 7. The benchmark and source code are made publicly available to facilitate further research on multi-view spatial reasoning in VLMs.
arXiv:2512.02340v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Spatial reasoning is a core aspect of human intelligence that allows perception, inference and planning in 3D environments. However, current vision-language models (VLMs) struggle to maintain geometric coherence and cross-view consistency for spatial reasoning in multi-view settings. We attribute this gap to the lack of fine-grained benchmarks that isolate multi-view reasoning from single-view perception and temporal factors. To address this, we present ReMindView-Bench, a cognitively grounded benchmark for evaluating how VLMs construct, align and maintain spatial mental models across complementary viewpoints. ReMindView-Bench systematically varies viewpoint spatial pattern and query type to probe key factors of spatial cognition. Evaluations of 15 current VLMs reveals consistent failures in cross-view alignment and perspective-taking in multi-view spatial reasoning, motivating deeper analysis on the reasoning process. Explicit phase-wise analysis using LLM-as-a-judge and self-consistency prompting shows that VLMs perform well on in-frame perception but degrade sharply when integrating information across views. Implicit analysis, including linear probing and entropy dynamics, further show progressive loss of task-relevant information and uncertainty separation between correct and incorrect trajectories. These results provide a cognitively grounded diagnosis of VLM spatial reasoning and reveal how multi-view spatial mental models are formed, degraded and destabilized across reasoning phases. The ReMindView-Bench benchmark is available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/Xue0823/ReMindView-Bench, and the source codes of benchmark construction and VLM reasoning analysis are available at https://github.com/pittisl/ReMindView-Bench.

item.title: Beyond Playtesting: A Generative Multi-Agent Simulation System for Massively Multiplayer Online Games
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: MMO games, Large Language Models, player behavior simulation, reinforcement learning, game design optimization

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of optimizing numerical systems and mechanism design in Massively Multiplayer Online (MMO) games, focusing on improving player experience without resorting to costly and disruptive large-scale online experiments. Traditional methods either depend on expensive online testing or simplified simulations, which lack fidelity and fail to accurately emulate real player reasoning and reactions. To overcome these limitations, the authors propose a novel generative agent-based MMO simulation system powered by Large Language Models (LLMs). The system uses Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) applied to extensive real player behavioral data, which adapts the generalized LLMs toward game-specific decision-making, enhancing realism and interpretability. Additionally, a data-driven environment model is built from real gameplay logs to reconstruct the dynamic in-game systems accurately. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach strongly reflects actual player behaviors and yields plausible causal responses when game parameters are adjusted. The proposed system offers a reliable, interpretable, and cost-efficient framework to facilitate data-driven numerical design optimization in MMO games, enabling better and faster iteration of game balancing and mechanism improvements, ultimately enhancing overall player engagement and satisfaction.
arXiv:2512.02358v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Optimizing numerical systems and mechanism design is crucial for enhancing player experience in Massively Multiplayer Online (MMO) games. Traditional optimization approaches rely on large-scale online experiments or parameter tuning over predefined statistical models, which are costly, time-consuming, and may disrupt player experience. Although simplified offline simulation systems are often adopted as alternatives, their limited fidelity prevents agents from accurately mimicking real player reasoning and reactions to interventions. To address these limitations, we propose a generative agent-based MMO simulation system empowered by Large Language Models (LLMs). By applying Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) on large-scale real player behavioral data, we adapt LLMs from general priors to game-specific domains, enabling realistic and interpretable player decision-making. In parallel, a data-driven environment model trained on real gameplay logs reconstructs dynamic in-game systems. Experiments demonstrate strong consistency with real-world player behaviors and plausible causal responses under interventions, providing a reliable, interpretable, and cost-efficient framework for data-driven numerical design optimization.

item.title: Synthetic Error Injection Fails to Elicit Self-Correction In Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: reinforcement learning, self-correction, synthetic error injection, supervised learning, distribution shift

Summary:

This paper investigates an alternative to reinforcement learning (RL) for enabling self-correction in large language models by using supervised learning with synthetic error injection. The authors draw inspiration from autonomous driving and robotics, where artificial errors are introduced into reasoning chains, masked, and the model is trained to detect and correct these errors. Despite the intuitive potential of this approach, experiments on simple synthetic tasks across multiple models show negligible performance improvements. A key finding is that even when the model identifies its own mistakes, it often ends up repeating the original error instead of correcting it. Furthermore, the study reveals that a distribution shift between synthetic errors used in training and the on-policy errors encountered during model deployment significantly impairs the model’s ability to self-correct. This degradation occurs despite comprehensive synthetic coverage of possible on-policy errors. The results provide insight into why reinforcement learning methods that involve on-policy error feedback have been particularly successful in eliciting robust self-correction capabilities in language models, a benefit that simple supervised learning with synthetic errors cannot replicate effectively.
arXiv:2512.02389v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement learning has become the dominant paradigm for eliciting reasoning and self-correction capabilities in large language models, but its computational expense motivates exploration of alternatives. Inspired by techniques from autonomous driving and robotics, we investigate whether supervised learning with synthetic error injection can induce self-correction abilities in language models. Our approach inserts artificial errors into reasoning chains, masks them, and supervises the model to recognize and correct these mistakes. Despite the intuitive appeal of this method, we find that it fails to significantly improve performance even on simple synthetic tasks across multiple models. Moreover, even when the model catches its own error, it often parrots the original mistake. We find that the distribution shift of synthetic errors to on-policy errors significantly degrades the error-correction capabilities of the fine-tuned model, even with good synthetic coverage of on-policy errors. Our results help explain why on-policy reinforcement learning methods have proven uniquely effective for eliciting self-correction.

item.title: Semantic Trading: Agentic AI for Clustering and Relationship Discovery in Prediction Markets
item.content:encoded:
prediction markets, agentic AI, natural-language understanding, market correlation, trading strategies

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of fragmentation in prediction markets caused by overlapping questions, implicit equivalences, and hidden contradictions among market offerings. The authors introduce an agentic AI pipeline that autonomously processes market data in two main steps: first, it clusters prediction markets into coherent topical groups by applying natural-language understanding to contract text and metadata; second, it identifies pairs of markets within each cluster whose outcomes are strongly dependent, including both correlated (same outcome) and anti-correlated (different outcomes) relationships. Using a historical dataset of resolved markets from Polymarket, the system’s ability to predict relational outcomes between market pairs is evaluated, demonstrating approximately 60-70% accuracy. Furthermore, the paper develops a simple trading strategy based on the agent-discovered relationships, which achieves around 20% average returns over week-long trading horizons. These results showcase the potential of agentic AI and large language models to uncover hidden semantic structures in prediction markets, offering insights that can improve market analysis and guide effective trading decisions.
arXiv:2512.02436v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Prediction markets allow users to trade on outcomes of real-world events, but are prone to fragmentation through overlapping questions, implicit equivalences, and hidden contradictions across markets. We present an agentic AI pipeline that autonomously (i) clusters markets into coherent topical groups using natural-language understanding over contract text and metadata, and (ii) identifies within-cluster market pairs whose resolved outcomes exhibit strong dependence, including same-outcome (correlated) and different-outcome (anti-correlated) relationships. Using a historical dataset of resolved markets on Polymarket, we evaluate the accuracy of the agent's relational predictions. We then translate discovered relationships into a simple trading strategy to quantify how these relationships map to actionable signals. Results show that agent-identified relationships achieve roughly 60-70% accuracy, and their induced trading strategies earn about 20% average returns over week-long horizons, highlighting the ability of agentic AI and large language models to uncover latent semantic structure in prediction markets.

item.title: Guided Self-Evolving LLMs with Minimal Human Supervision
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: AI self-evolution, guided self-play, Challenger-Solver framework, curriculum training, concept drift prevention

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of AI self-evolution, where models autonomously improve from their own learning, but notes common issues such as plateauing, concept drift, diversity collapse, and bias reinforcement that hinder progress.

2. To overcome these problems, the authors propose R-Few, a guided Self-Play Challenger-Solver framework that incorporates lightweight human oversight through in-context grounding and mixed training with both human-labeled and synthetically generated examples.

3. R-Few operates in iterative cycles: the Challenger generates synthetic questions guided by a small set of human-labeled instances, and the Solver trains on an evolving difficulty-based curriculum combining human and synthetic data.

4. Experiments across mathematics and general reasoning benchmarks demonstrate that R-Few consistently produces iterative improvements, exemplified by Qwen3-8B-Base's +3.0 point gain over R-Zero on math tasks, matching the performance of a model trained on 20 times more human data.

5. Ablation studies validate the importance of both grounded challenger training and curriculum-based solver training, while further analysis reveals that R-Few effectively mitigates concept drift and fosters more stable and controllable co-evolutionary dynamics during self-evolution.
arXiv:2512.02472v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: AI self-evolution has long been envisioned as a path toward superintelligence, where models autonomously acquire, refine, and internalize knowledge from their own learning experiences. Yet in practice, unguided self-evolving systems often plateau quickly or even degrade as training progresses. These failures arise from issues such as concept drift, diversity collapse, and mis-evolution, as models reinforce their own biases and converge toward low-entropy behaviors. To enable models to self-evolve in a stable and controllable manner while minimizing reliance on human supervision, we introduce R-Few, a guided Self-Play Challenger-Solver framework that incorporates lightweight human oversight through in-context grounding and mixed training. At each iteration, the Challenger samples a small set of human-labeled examples to guide synthetic question generation, while the Solver jointly trains on human and synthetic examples under an online, difficulty-based curriculum. Across math and general reasoning benchmarks, R-Few achieves consistent and iterative improvements. For example, Qwen3-8B-Base improves by +3.0 points over R-Zero on math tasks and achieves performance on par with General-Reasoner, despite the latter being trained on 20 times more human data. Ablation studies confirm the complementary contributions of grounded challenger training and curriculum-based solver training, and further analysis shows that R-Few mitigates drift, yielding more stable and controllable co-evolutionary dynamics.

item.title: COPE: Chain-Of-Thought Prediction Engine for Open-Source Large Language Model Based Stroke Outcome Prediction from Clinical Notes
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: acute ischemic stroke, outcome prediction, Chain-of-Thought, large language model, clinical notes

Summary: 1. This study focuses on predicting 90-day functional outcomes after acute ischemic stroke (AIS) by analyzing unstructured clinical notes. 2. The authors developed the Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Outcome Prediction Engine (COPE), leveraging a two-step reasoning framework using open-source LLaMA-3-8B models. The first step generates clinical reasoning, and the second produces a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) prediction. 3. The dataset comprised 464 AIS patients, including discharge summaries and their corresponding 90-day mRS scores. 4. COPE’s performance was benchmarked against GPT-4.1, ClinicalBERT, a structured variable-based machine learning model (Clinical ML), and a single-step large language model without CoT. 5. COPE achieved strong predictive results with a mean absolute error (MAE) of 1.01, +/-1 point accuracy of 74.4%, and exact accuracy of 32.8%, which was comparable to GPT-4.1 and superior to other models tested. 6. Subgroup analyses indicated consistent performance across sex and age groups, though marginally higher errors were observed in older patients, those undergoing thrombectomy, and with longer clinical summaries. 7. The study highlights COPE as a lightweight, interpretable, privacy-preserving, and practical open-source tool for clinical outcome prediction from unstructured textual data.
arXiv:2512.02499v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Predicting outcomes in acute ischemic stroke (AIS) guides clinical decision-making, patient counseling, and resource allocation. Clinical notes contain rich contextual information, but their unstructured nature limits their use in traditional predictive models. We developed and evaluated the Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Outcome Prediction Engine (COPE), a reasoning-enhanced large language model framework, for predicting 90-day functional outcomes after AIS from unstructured clinical notes. This study included 464 AIS patients with discharge summaries and 90-day modified Rankin Scale (mRS) scores. COPE uses a two-step CoT framework based on sequential open-source LLaMA-3-8B models: the first generates clinical reasoning, and the second outputs an mRS prediction. We compared COPE with GPT-4.1, ClinicalBERT, a structured variable-based machine learning model (Clinical ML), and a single-step LLM without CoT. Performance was evaluated using mean absolute error (MAE), accuracy within +/-1 mRS point, and exact accuracy. COPE achieved an MAE of 1.01 (95% CI 0.92-1.11), +/-1 accuracy of 74.4% (69.9, 78.8%), and exact accuracy of 32.8% (28.0, 37.6%), comparable to GPT-4.1 and superior to ClinicalBERT [MAE 1.24 (1.13-1.36)], Clinical ML [1.28 (1.18-1.39)], and the single-step LLM [1.20 (1.09-1.33)]. Subgroup analyses showed consistent performance across sex and age, with slightly higher error among older patients, those undergoing thrombectomy, and those with longer summaries. These findings demonstrate that COPE, a lightweight, interpretable, and privacy-preserving open-source framework, provides an accurate and practical solution for outcome prediction from unstructured clinical text.

item.title: Aetheria: A multimodal interpretable content safety framework based on multi-agent debate and collaboration
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal content safety, multi-agent debate, interpretable moderation, RAG-based retrieval, implicit risk detection

Summary:

1. The paper addresses challenges in digital content safety due to the exponential growth of digital content and limitations of current moderation systems that rely on single models or fixed pipelines. 2. It introduces Aetheria, a novel multimodal content safety framework that uses a multi-agent system based on debate and collaboration to analyze and moderate content more effectively. 3. Aetheria consists of five core collaborative agents that engage in a dynamic and mutually persuasive debate, supported by Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for knowledge retrieval, enhancing both the depth and accuracy of content analysis. 4. The framework produces detailed, interpretable, and traceable audit reports, advancing transparency in AI content moderation. 5. Experimental results on the proposed AIR-Bench benchmark demonstrate that Aetheria outperforms traditional approaches, particularly in identifying implicit risks, thereby establishing a new paradigm for trustworthy and interpretable content moderation systems.
arXiv:2512.02530v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The exponential growth of digital content presents significant challenges for content safety. Current moderation systems, often based on single models or fixed pipelines, exhibit limitations in identifying implicit risks and providing interpretable judgment processes. To address these issues, we propose Aetheria, a multimodal interpretable content safety framework based on multi-agent debate and collaboration.Employing a collaborative architecture of five core agents, Aetheria conducts in-depth analysis and adjudication of multimodal content through a dynamic, mutually persuasive debate mechanism, which is grounded by RAG-based knowledge retrieval.Comprehensive experiments on our proposed benchmark (AIR-Bench) validate that Aetheria not only generates detailed and traceable audit reports but also demonstrates significant advantages over baselines in overall content safety accuracy, especially in the identification of implicit risks. This framework establishes a transparent and interpretable paradigm, significantly advancing the field of trustworthy AI content moderation.

item.title: Empathy Level Prediction in Multi-Modal Scenario with Supervisory Documentation Assistance
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multi-modal empathy prediction, privileged information, cross-modal fusion, Latent Dirichlet Allocation, supervisory documents

Summary: This paper addresses the limitations of current empathy prediction techniques that largely focus on a single modality, usually text, and often ignore valuable privileged information. The authors propose an advanced multi-modal empathy prediction method that integrates video, audio, and text data. The approach consists of two main components: Multi-Modal Empathy Prediction and Supervisory Documentation Assisted Training. Pre-trained networks are used to extract features from each modality, which are then combined through cross-modal fusion to form comprehensive multi-modal feature representations for empathy label prediction. To improve text feature extraction, the method incorporates supervisory documents as privileged information during training. These documents, created by supervisors, highlight counseling topics and empathetic behaviors, and are employed to constrain text features by applying the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) model to reveal topic distributions. Importantly, this privileged information is only utilized during the training phase and is unavailable during prediction, ensuring practical deployment. Extensive experiments on multi-modal and dialogue empathy datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms existing methods, validating the effectiveness of integrating multi-modal data and leveraging supervisory privileged information.
arXiv:2512.02558v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Prevalent empathy prediction techniques primarily concentrate on a singular modality, typically textual, thus neglecting multi-modal processing capabilities. They also overlook the utilization of certain privileged information, which may encompass additional empathetic content. In response, we introduce an advanced multi-modal empathy prediction method integrating video, audio, and text information. The method comprises the Multi-Modal Empathy Prediction and Supervisory Documentation Assisted Training. We use pre-trained networks in the empathy prediction network to extract features from various modalities, followed by a cross-modal fusion. This process yields a multi-modal feature representation, which is employed to predict empathy labels. To enhance the extraction of text features, we incorporate supervisory documents as privileged information during the assisted training phase. Specifically, we apply the Latent Dirichlet Allocation model to identify potential topic distributions to constrain text features. These supervisory documents, created by supervisors, focus on the counseling topics and the counselor's display of empathy. Notably, this privileged information is only available during training and is not accessible during the prediction phase. Experimental results on the multi-modal and dialogue empathy datasets demonstrate that our approach is superior to the existing methods.

item.title: PaperDebugger: A Plugin-Based Multi-Agent System for In-Editor Academic Writing, Review, and Editing
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PaperDebugger, academic writing assistant, LaTeX editor, multi-agent system, Model Context Protocol (MCP)

Summary: PaperDebugger is an innovative academic writing assistant designed to integrate large language model (LLM)-driven reasoning directly within LaTeX editors like Overleaf. Unlike existing external assistants, it enables deep, context-aware interactions with the document’s state, structure, and revision history to improve editing workflows. Developing this in-editor capability requires overcoming challenges such as reliable bidirectional synchronization with the editor, fine-grained version control and patching, secure state management, multi-agent task scheduling, and extensible communication with external tools. To address these, PaperDebugger employs a Chrome-approved browser extension paired with a Kubernetes-native orchestration layer that manages multi-agent coordination efficiently. The system incorporates a Model Context Protocol (MCP) toolchain which integrates several key functionalities including literature search, reference lookup, document scoring, and structured revision pipelines. The demo highlights features such as localized edits, structured reviews, parallel execution of multiple agents, and updates based on document diffs, all presented in a minimal-intrusion user interface to preserve writing flow. Early usage analytics indicate active engagement from users, validating the practicality and effectiveness of an editor-native, agentic academic writing assistant. The project offers an open-source demo and video accessible via their GitHub repository.
arXiv:2512.02589v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models are increasingly embedded into academic writing workflows, yet existing assistants remain external to the editor, preventing deep interaction with document state, structure, and revision history. This separation makes it impossible to support agentic, context-aware operations directly within LaTeX editors such as Overleaf. We present PaperDebugger, an in-editor, multi-agent, and plugin-based academic writing assistant that brings LLM-driven reasoning directly into the writing environment. Enabling such in-editor interaction is technically non-trivial: it requires reliable bidirectional synchronization with the editor, fine-grained version control and patching, secure state management, multi-agent scheduling, and extensible communication with external tools. PaperDebugger addresses these challenges through a Chrome-approved extension, a Kubernetes-native orchestration layer, and a Model Context Protocol (MCP) toolchain that integrates literature search, reference lookup, document scoring, and revision pipelines. Our demo showcases a fully integrated workflow, including localized edits, structured reviews, parallel agent execution, and diff-based updates, encapsulated within a minimal-intrusion user interface (UI). Early aggregated analytics demonstrate active user engagement and validate the practicality of an editor-native, agentic writing assistant. More details about this demo and video could be found at https://github.com/PaperDebugger/PaperDebugger.

item.title: IACT: A Self-Organizing Recursive Model for General AI Agents: A Technical White Paper on the Architecture Behind kragent.ai
item.content:encoded:
Interactive Agents, Call Tree, autonomous system, error correction, dynamic topology

Summary:

This paper presents the Interactive Agents Call Tree (IACT), a novel computational model designed to overcome the constraints of static, hard-coded agent workflows. Unlike traditional models that depend on pre-defined graphs or specialized programming, IACT dynamically creates a recursive, multi-agent topology based solely on user dialogue and high-level objectives, enabling it to scale organizational complexity according to task demands. The system fosters open-ended problem solving by incrementally building its agent structure tailored to the specific problem. A key innovation is the introduction of interactional redundancy through bidirectional, stateful dialogues replacing unidirectional function calls, which helps mitigate error propagation common in conventional agent interactions. This bidirectional communication enables the system to perform runtime error correction and resolve ambiguities effectively. The paper details the design principles and architecture of IACT, sharing practical insights gained from its real-world deployment in the kragent.ai platform. Instead of relying on benchmark evaluations, the authors provide qualitative evidence demonstrating IACT’s effectiveness in handling complex workflows autonomously, emphasizing its potential for scalable and adaptive agent-based systems.
arXiv:2512.02605v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This technical white paper introduces the Interactive Agents Call Tree (IACT), a computational model designed to address the limitations of static, hard-coded agent workflows. Unlike traditional systems that require pre-defined graphs or specialized programming, IACT operates as a general-purpose autonomous system driven purely by user dialogue. Given a high-level objective, the system autonomously grows a dynamic, recursive agent topology incrementally tailored to the problem's structure. This allows it to scale its organizational complexity to match open-ended tasks. To mitigate the error propagation inherent in unidirectional function calls, IACT introduces interactional redundancy by replacing rigid invocations with bidirectional, stateful dialogues. This mechanism enables runtime error correction and ambiguity resolution. We describe the architecture, design principles, and practical lessons behind the production deployment of this model in the kragent.ai system, presenting qualitative evidence from real-world workflows rather than exhaustive benchmark results.

item.title: Target-specific Adaptation and Consistent Degradation Alignment for Cross-Domain Remaining Useful Life Prediction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Remaining Useful Life, domain adaptation, target domain reconstruction, clustering strategy, machinery maintenance

Summary:

1. Accurate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction is vital for reducing maintenance costs, improving equipment uptime, and avoiding negative outcomes in industrial machinery.
2. Existing data-driven RUL prediction models assume training and testing data come from the same distribution, which is often invalid in real-world industrial environments, causing performance issues.
3. Prior adversarial domain adaptation methods aim to learn domain-invariant features but neglect target-specific information and the inconsistencies related to different degradation stages.
4. The proposed TACDA method introduces a target domain reconstruction strategy during adversarial adaptation to preserve target-specific information alongside domain-invariant features.
5. TACDA also employs a novel clustering and pairing approach to consistently align data points from similar degradation stages across domains.
6. Extensive experiments demonstrate that TACDA outperforms state-of-the-art methods on two evaluation metrics for cross-domain RUL prediction.
7. The code for TACDA is publicly available at https://github.com/keyplay/TACDA, facilitating replication and further research.
arXiv:2512.02610v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Accurate prediction of the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) in machinery can significantly diminish maintenance costs, enhance equipment up-time, and mitigate adverse outcomes. Data-driven RUL prediction techniques have demonstrated commendable performance. However, their efficacy often relies on the assumption that training and testing data are drawn from the same distribution or domain, which does not hold in real industrial settings. To mitigate this domain discrepancy issue, prior adversarial domain adaptation methods focused on deriving domain-invariant features. Nevertheless, they overlook target-specific information and inconsistency characteristics pertinent to the degradation stages, resulting in suboptimal performance. To tackle these issues, we propose a novel domain adaptation approach for cross-domain RUL prediction named TACDA. Specifically, we propose a target domain reconstruction strategy within the adversarial adaptation process, thereby retaining target-specific information while learning domain-invariant features. Furthermore, we develop a novel clustering and pairing strategy for consistent alignment between similar degradation stages. Through extensive experiments, our results demonstrate the remarkable performance of our proposed TACDA method, surpassing state-of-the-art approaches with regard to two different evaluation metrics. Our code is available at https://github.com/keyplay/TACDA.

item.title: Zero-Shot Instruction Following in RL via Structured LTL Representations
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: linear temporal logic, reinforcement learning, finite automata, graph neural network, multi-task policy

Summary:

1. The paper focuses on the use of linear temporal logic (LTL) as a framework for specifying complex and structured tasks for reinforcement learning (RL) agents.

2. It builds on recent work that interprets LTL instructions as finite automata, which serve as high-level monitoring programs, enabling the training of a single generalist RL policy capable of executing arbitrary LTL tasks at test time.

3. Current approaches struggle in environments where multiple atomic propositions may be true simultaneously and can interact in complex ways, limiting their effectiveness.

4. To address this, the authors propose a new method that conditions the RL policy on sequences of simple Boolean formulae, which better align with automaton transitions, allowing a structured and more expressive representation of task progress.

5. These sequences are encoded using a graph neural network (GNN), yielding improved structured task representations.

6. Empirical evaluation in a challenging chess-based environment demonstrates that this approach outperforms existing methods, showing better adaptability and performance in multi-event, interacting scenarios.
arXiv:2512.02633v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Linear temporal logic (LTL) is a compelling framework for specifying complex, structured tasks for reinforcement learning (RL) agents. Recent work has shown that interpreting LTL instructions as finite automata, which can be seen as high-level programs monitoring task progress, enables learning a single generalist policy capable of executing arbitrary instructions at test time. However, existing approaches fall short in environments where multiple high-level events (i.e., atomic propositions) can be true at the same time and potentially interact in complicated ways. In this work, we propose a novel approach to learning a multi-task policy for following arbitrary LTL instructions that addresses this shortcoming. Our method conditions the policy on sequences of simple Boolean formulae, which directly align with transitions in the automaton, and are encoded via a graph neural network (GNN) to yield structured task representations. Experiments in a complex chess-based environment demonstrate the advantages of our approach.

item.title: Exploring Depth Generalization in Large Language Models for Solving Recursive Logic Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: depth generalization, recursive reasoning, transformer limitations, looped locate-and-replace, hierarchical problems

Summary: Large language models (LLMs), despite their broad success, face notable difficulties with recursive reasoning challenges involving nested hierarchical structures. This research distinguishes depth generalization—the ability to handle problems with multiple levels of nesting—from the more commonly studied length generalization, emphasizing that transformers struggle particularly with deeper recursion. The paper identifies that standard transformer architectures cannot maintain stack-like behavior necessary for tracking multiple nested dependencies, causing their performance to rapidly decline as recursion depth increases. To mitigate this limitation, the authors propose a looped locate-and-replace pipeline that breaks down complex recursive problems into smaller, solvable subexpressions. This framework uses two specialized models: a locator to find solvable subexpressions and a replacer to evaluate these components while preserving the hierarchical structure. The approach was tested in three domains—Boolean algebra, recursive arithmetic, and propositional logic—each allowing for controlled recursion depth. Results demonstrate that this method significantly improves performance on problems with deeper nested structures beyond the training distribution, effectively addressing the depth generalization challenge encountered by conventional transformers.
arXiv:2512.02677v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across many tasks, yet face significant challenges when dealing with recursive reasoning problems, those requiring the resolution of nested hierarchical structures. While prior research has extensively studied length generalization (a model's ability to handle longer sequences than seen during training), we investigate a distinct and underexplored limitation: depth generalization. Here, depth refers to the number of nested levels in a hierarchical problem, such as the layers of parentheses in a mathematical expression or the nesting of logical clauses in a Boolean formula. Our work reveals that standard transformer architectures struggle with problems involving deeper recursion than encountered during training, even when they perform well on longer but non-nested sequences. This limitation stems from their inability to maintain stack-like behavior, the capacity to track and resolve multiple levels of nested dependencies. Through systematic analysis, we demonstrate how this architectural constraint leads to rapid performance decay as the depth of the recursion increases. To address this challenge, we develop a novel looped locate-and-replace pipeline that decomposes recursive problems into manageable subcomponents. The approach employs two specialized models: a locator that identifies solvable subexpressions and a replacer that evaluates these components while preserving the overall structure. We evaluated this method in three carefully designed domains: Boolean algebra, recursive arithmetic, and propositional logic, each with a controllable depth of recursion. We show that our method effectively alleviates the performance decay when tested on out-of-distribution recursion depth.

item.title: Learning What to Attend First: Modality-Importance-Guided Reasoning for Reliable Multimodal Emotion Understanding
item.content:encoded:
Modality Importance, Reasoning Drift, Multimodal Emotion Understanding, Large Language Models, Explanation Coherence

Summary:

1. The paper introduces Modality-Importance-Guided Reasoning (MIGR), a framework to enhance the reliability of reasoning in multimodal large language models focused on emotion understanding.
2. Existing methods often experience reasoning drift, where models increasingly rely on their own generated text rather than multimodal evidence, and explanations become biased toward visually driven reasoning.
3. MIGR addresses these challenges by introducing Modality Importance (MI), a mechanism that identifies the dominant modality responsible for conveying the target emotion.
4. Using MI, MIGR restructures the reasoning sequence to begin with the most emotionally relevant modality, reducing the likelihood of being misled by less informative cues.
5. The framework employs a two-stage approach combining modality-aligned supervised fine-tuning and modality-aware reward optimization to encourage emotionally grounded, causally relevant, and coherent explanations.
6. Experimental evaluation on the DFEW benchmark demonstrates that MIGR significantly improves reasoning reliability, reducing the rate of correct predictions paired with emotionally inconsistent explanations from 18.10% to 7.37%.
7. The results validate the importance of initiating reasoning processes from the emotion-dominant modality for improved model explanation quality.
arXiv:2512.02699v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this paper, we present Modality-Importance-Guided Reasoning (MIGR), a framework designed to improve the reliability of reasoning-based multimodal emotion understanding in multimodal large language models. Although existing methods have advanced emotion understanding, they often suffer from reasoning drift: models gradually rely on their own generated text instead of multimodal evidence, and their explanations are overly shaped by visually initiated reasoning paths. To address these issues, we introduce Modality Importance (MI), a simple yet effective mechanism for identifying the emotion-dominant modality. Using MI, MIGR reorganizes reasoning sequences so that explanations begin from the modality most critical to the target emotion, preventing early reasoning from being misled by less informative cues. Our two-stage framework-comprising modality-aligned supervised fine-tuning and modality-aware reward optimization-encourages models to generate emotionally grounded, causally relevant, and coherence-preserving explanations. Experimental results on the DFEW benchmark show that MIGR substantially improves reasoning reliability, decreasing instances of correct predictions accompanied by emotionally inconsistent explanations from 18.10% to 7.37%. These results confirm the benefit of initiating reasoning from the emotion-dominant modality.

item.title: Training Data Attribution for Image Generation using Ontology-Aligned Knowledge Graphs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: generative models, knowledge graphs, ontology alignment, multimodal large language models, copyright analysis

Summary: This paper addresses the growing concerns about transparency, accountability, and copyright issues in generative AI models by proposing a novel framework that interprets generative outputs through automatically constructed ontology-aligned knowledge graphs (KGs). First, it notes the challenge of extracting structured and ontology-consistent representations from image data, given their rich and multi-object nature. To overcome this, the authors leverage multimodal large language models (LLMs) to extract structured triples from images that align with domain-specific ontologies. By constructing KGs for both generated and training images, their method facilitates tracing potential influences of training data on model outputs. This capability enables copyright analysis, improved dataset transparency, and the interpretability of AI-generated content. The framework is experimentally validated through two approaches: one involving unlearning on locally trained models, and another using style-specific experiments on large-scale models. Ultimately, the work supports the development of AI systems designed to promote human collaboration, creativity, and curiosity by making model behavior more interpretable and accountable.
arXiv:2512.02713v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As generative models become powerful, concerns around transparency, accountability, and copyright violations have intensified. Understanding how specific training data contributes to a model's output is critical. We introduce a framework for interpreting generative outputs through the automatic construction of ontologyaligned knowledge graphs (KGs). While automatic KG construction from natural text has advanced, extracting structured and ontology-consistent representations from visual content remains challenging -- due to the richness and multi-object nature of images. Leveraging multimodal large language models (LLMs), our method extracts structured triples from images, aligned with a domain-specific ontology. By comparing the KGs of generated and training images, we can trace potential influences, enabling copyright analysis, dataset transparency, and interpretable AI. We validate our method through experiments on locally trained models via unlearning, and on large-scale models through a style-specific experiment. Our framework supports the development of AI systems that foster human collaboration, creativity and stimulate curiosity.

item.title: Menta: A Small Language Model for On-Device Mental Health Prediction
item.content:encoded:
